—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. I note that the minister has said that there was `no security crisis of any significant kind' associated with the expulsion of six Russian spies last year. If this is the case, why were they expelled?
—It was a security issue but not a crisis. Beyond that I have no further comment.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Bearing in mind that the minister is not going to tell us—presumably, he is not going to expand on what he told the press, which was that they were engaged in inappropriate activities—would he explain to the Senate and thereby to the Australian people why these particular persons, who had been cleared by ASIO before they were allowed to enter Australia, should not know why they were expelled from this country? What is the minister hiding?

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy and relates to the natural gas market in Australia. Can the minister inform the Senate about recent progress in reforms of the natural gas industry arising out of the meeting of the Council of Australian Governments in Hobart last Friday?

—I welcome the very real progress that was made at COAG towards implementing free and fair interstate trade in natural gas. Such an agreement was a long time coming. The matter has been on the COAG agenda now for some years, and I am pleased that it was brought to a resolution.

PARA.TAB: Free and fair trade in natural gas, including arrangements for third party access to pipelines, represents one of the key objectives of the federal government's national gas strategy. The COAG decision means that arrangements will now be put in place to allow gas consumers and producers in any state or territory to buy or sell gas in any other state or territory on normal commercial terms. This will lead to the best possible use of Australia's gas resources and the lowest possible prices for consumers.

COAG's approach will also stimulate development of a truly national gas industry by increasing the market area and doing away with artificial regulatory barriers at state borders, which is obviously a sensible arrangement for a geographically diffuse nation which is rich in natural gas. As a consequence of the COAG agreement, I announced at the weekend that the Interstate Gas Pipelines Bill, which is currently before this Senate, will be deferred. The bill, which was introduced late last year, was designed to address many of the commercial transparency and third party access issues that have now been agreed upon in Hobart. The eventual fate of the bill will rest with how readily state and territory governments move to implement the decisions that were reached by COAG. However, I expect the goodwill and commitment demonstrated in Hobart to carry over into action and the agreed national framework to be in place by the deadline of 1 July 1996.

The agreed features of this framework to be put into place are as follows: no legislative or regulatory barriers to interstate and intrastate trade in gas; third party access rights to both interstate and intrastate supply networks; uniform national pipeline construction standards; increased commercialisation of the operations of publicly owned gas utilities; no restrictions on the uses of natural gas—for example, for electricity generation; and, finally, gas franchise arrangements consistent with free and fair competition in the gas market and third party access.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I refer to the minister's recent appearance on Meet the Press when he claimed that the Parliamentary Privileges Act of 1987, which was introduced by him into the Senate at that time, had never contemplated that parliament should be allowed to impose penalties, including gaol, on public servants. Could he therefore please explain why in 1984 the report of the Joint Select Committee on Parliamentary Privilege, which was the basis for the 1987 legislation and of which committee he was then the deputy chairman, said, `For the system to work effectively it must have the power to compel the attendance of witnesses . . . and the production of documents . . . We think the sanction of imprisonment should remain'? Why has the minister once again changed his story to suit his political convenience? Is this not just another classic example of his willingness to say or do anything in a manic determination to stay in office?

—There is only one person displaying any mania at the moment, and it is not me. I remember very clearly the context of that Senate committee inquiry because I was a member of it, as Senator Alston says. Clearly what we were concerned about was that there be an appropriate set of sanctions to deal with breaches of privilege. This could, in an appropriate situation, involve non-cooperation of witnesses in various ways. Unquestionably the main context in which we thought it was not only desirable but indeed necessary to maintain the sanction was, as I said the other day, in the context of gross intimidation of parliamentarians, or intimidation or standing over of witnesses, or some other extreme manifestation of behaviour of that kind which would make it totally inappropriate for the behaviour in question to go unpunished—and punished in an extreme way, not just a slap over the wrist.

PARA.TAB: It will be remembered that the context of that privileges committee inquiry was also one in which the committee was at pains to recommend, and the parliament agreed, that there should no longer be any offence of defamation of parliament or parliamentarians, which was the context, of course, in which imprisonment had been handed out in that disgraceful case of Browne and Fitzpatrick back in the 1950s. But in the context of other possible breaches of privilege and in particular the extreme ones, the situation is as I described it. I cannot recall a single conversation in that committee which in any way had regard to—let alone came forward with an explicit recommendation—the possibility of public servants being imprisoned for acting in accordance with legitimate executive directions in this matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The minister was on that committee for several years, he was indeed the deputy chairman in opposition, and remained on that committee as deputy chairman when he was Attorney-General through to 1984. Is he seriously telling the Senate that he was not then conscious of the 1975 privileges resolution which said that the fact that a person summonsed is an officer of the Public Service or that a question related to his departmental duties does not of itself excuse or preclude an officer from answering the question or from producing a file? Is he seriously saying that that was not clearly in contemplation, that he was not fully aware of that, and therefore when he told Meet the Press that it had never been contemplated that legislation should apply to allow parliament to service its privileges in that way, he was simply once again, last Sunday, disguising the real truth?

—The Senate has said and resolved all sorts of silly things in the past when it has had opposition majorities in control of it. I on occasion, I have to readily concede, as I did in this place the other day, have been party in the past to some of those misconceived exercises when I have been an exuberant advocate in opposition. But when one is in government and one has the role of not only being an advocate but a judge on matters that go directly to the public interest one grows up. And we have grown up with the experience of the past 10 years, and we have realised the kinds of delicate balances that are involved in this respect.

PARA.TAB: I have to say that I have grown up quite considerably in my experience of government and in my understanding of the delicate balance of public interest that is involved in these situations. Senator Alston is the boy who never grew up. What is more, he will never get a chance to grow up because the Australian electorate will not give it to him.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. I refer to the inflammatory remarks made yesterday by Victorian Premier Kennett and other federal coalition politicians at the Greek rally in Melbourne which seriously misrepresented the elements underlying the government's decision to recognise the Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia. Will the minister once again explain why the Australian government has recognised the Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia and outline the conditions which the government has applied to the possible establishment of a Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia consulate?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday I described Mr Kennett's speech to the Greek rally in Melbourne as the worst kind of disgraceful political opportunism, and I do not resile from that. I have also conveyed, I have to say, my sentiments in that respect directly to Senator Short, who also attended and spoke at that rally, giving, if anything, an even more partisan speech than did the Victorian Premier.

PARA.TAB: I explained fully the reasons for the government decision and why it did not involve any breach of the commitments given two years ago by Prime Minister Keating in the original statement I made on this matter on 15 February. I seek leave to incorporate the full text of that statement in Hansard .
Leave granted.
The document read as follows—

ANSWER.PARA: 15 February 1994
FORMER YUGOSLAV REPUBLIC OF MACEDONIA (FYROM)

Australia has decided to recognise as an independent state, and to commence discussions on diplomatic relations with, the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia. Australia will refer to the Republic as "The Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia" (FYROM), the temporary name used in the UN and for membership of some international agencies.

The FYROM has been formally recognised by some 59 states (including, last week, the United States of America). Along with 62 other countries, including Greece, Australia co-sponsored the admission of the FYROM to the UN in April 1993. According to the practice of many of those co-sponsors, recognition of the FYROM flowed automatically from support for its admission to the UN; for Australia, recognition required a separate formal act, and that step has now been taken.

As I assured the Greek Government during my visit to Athens last month, in recognising the FYROM, Australia makes no presumption as to the final outcome of the "name" issue, or any other issue involved in negotiations between Greece and the Republic.

We do believe those negotiations would be much assisted by the Government in Skopje ceasing to use the "Star of Vergina" symbol on the FYROM's flag; forbearing from using the name "Republic of Macedonia" until a mutually acceptable final resolution of the name issue is achieved; addressing the provisions of FYROM's Constitution which continue to cause concern in Greece; and taking all possible steps to curb the proliferation, at home and abroad, of offensive irredentist propaganda. We urge the Government of the FYROM to act accordingly.

The Australian Government also stands ready to enter into diplomatic relations with the FYROM, joining, among many others in this respect, all of Greece's major European partners. We will consider a request from the authorities in Skopje to open a Consulate in Australia which will be able to provide a full range of needed consular services to the local community (some 75,000 people) in Australia.

I have instructed the Australian Embassy in Belgrade to pursue the necessary practical arrangements. Our agreement to the opening of a FYROM Consulate in Australia would be subject to the conditions that it describe itself appropriately (as the Consulate of the "Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia", not as the "Republic of Macedonia"), and that no contentious flag or other symbol be displayed pending final resolution of relevant outstanding issues. Our early agreement to the opening of a Consulate would be much assisted by a statement on the public record by the Government of the FYROM that it is prepared to act immediately, or at least as soon as the necessary legislative majority is achievable, to change the country's flag.

On 3 March 1992, Prime Minister Keating identified three matters about which Australia would need to be satisfied before proceeding to recognition. We believe, in the light of the course of events since then and our discussions with relevant governments, that these conditions are now met.

As to the first of these matters—"the use of the word `Macedonia' being settled in the way that does not cause further tension with Greece"—the situation is that while the name issue has still not been finally resolved, it has been satisfactorily settled for the time being by the international community (including Greece itself accepting for various purposes the temporary name "Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia".

As to the second matter—"Greece's concern about possible territorial claims or aspirations being fully met"—the amendment to the FYROM's Constitution in July 1992 (spelling out that the country "has no territorial pretensions towards any neighbouring states"), together with President Gligorov's restatements (most recently on 10 February 1994) of Skopje's acceptance of existing boundaries between the two countries, has reinforced the earlier conclusion of the Badinter Commission that FYROM had no territorial aspirations.

And as to the third matter—"the international community's concern about the protection of minorities being fully satisfied"—the recognition action now taken by so many European and other countries has signified acceptance of the Badinter Commission's findings that FYROM's constitutional guarantees on human rights are comparable with the rest of Europe and satisfy recognition standards.

The Australian Government is pleased to note the calmer and more constructive atmosphere that has been apparent, in recent times, in discussion of the issues which remain outstanding between Greece and the FYROM. The fact that the two states are geographical neighbours makes it necessary that they be able to deal with each other on a daily basis with mutual respect and confidence. We hope and expect that it will be possible for the outstanding issues to be amicably resolved in the not too distant future.

TALK.START.PARA: —While I have not got the time to go through all the detail now, I will state the key elements underlying the government's recognition decision in these terms. In the first place Australian recognition of states is based not on approval or disapproval but on objective criteria. Those criteria—identifiable boundaries, an established government and a measure of international acceptance of the country as a state—have clearly been satisfied for some time in the case of the Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia.

PARA.TAB: Secondly, it was simply no longer tenable for Australia to hold out any longer against recognition when 58 other countries, including all the other countries of the European Union and most recently the United States, had recognised the country. It was not a matter of our blindly following the United States, but rather acknowledging the reality that once the United States had moved on this issue no policy leverage of any useful kind could be exercised by withholding recognition.

Thirdly, once the Former Yugoslav Republic was admitted to the UN last year, with Greece itself co-sponsoring that admission and Greece itself accepting for this purpose the temporary name `Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia', or FYROM, it was inevitable that international recognition would follow. Fourthly, Mr Peacock, the opposition spokesman, squarely accepted this in his own statement that he put out on behalf of the opposition on 15 February when he said:

ANSWER.PARA: The Shadow Minister for Foreign Affairs, Honourable. Andrew Peacock, today acknowledged that Australia's decision to recognise the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia as an independent state was consistent with that state's membership of the United Nations.

TALK.START.PARA: —What else did he say?

—He then went on to give a flick against Mr Keating, yes, but he acknowledged the basic consistency and inevitability. Because he is a crude and vulgar politician, like the rest of the opposition, he could not stop himself there. But on the basic issue he acknowledged the inevitability, he acknowledged the consistency.

PARA.TAB: Finally, the terms of Australia's recognition have been terms that bent over backwards to meet the concern of Greek community leaders. In particular, a FYROM consulate will only be able to be opened in Australia if it describes itself appropriately, not as the `Republic of Macedonia', and if it does not display the Star of Vergina or any other contentious symbol.

Finally, let me say this: there are two bottom lines for the Australian government in this matter which should be clearly appreciated by all of those who are determined, for whatever motives, honourable or otherwise, to pursue the politics of division in this country. First, the Australian government will always conduct Australia's foreign policy to protect and advance Australia's national interests, not those of any other country. Secondly, this government will always govern for all Australians in a way which seeks to protect and assist members of all minority groups in our community, not just those who shout or threaten the loudest.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I take a point of order. The minister sought the leave of the Senate to incorporate a statement in Hansard, and leave was granted. I ask that he now incorporate the whole of the statement by the opposition spokesman, Andrew Peacock, and not just the out-of-context sentence that he quoted.

—Mr President, I am perfectly happy to do so because the paragraph I quoted was the first paragraph in the release and it was consistent with an undertaking given to me by Mr Peacock that the opposition would accept as inevitable, and consistent with the admission to the UN, our words of recognition of FYROM.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

ANSWER.PARA: Press Release by Hon. Andrew Peacock, MP, Shadow Minister for Foreign Affairs
Government Approach to `Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia' Flawed

The Shadow Minister for Foreign Affairs, Honourable. Andrew Peacock, today acknowledged that Australia's decision to recognise the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia as an independent state was consistent with that state's membership of the United Nations.
But Mr Peacock said the Government's approach was nevertheless flawed.
Mr Peacock said he has reservations about the Government's formal diplomatic use, even on a temporary basis, of the name `The Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia'.

Mr Peacock said he does not accept the Government's claim that all three of the conditions for recognition laid down by Prime Minister Keating on 3 March 1992 have been met. He said the Government has effectively broken the Prime Minister's undertaking not to proceed to recognition until basic outstanding questions are resolved.
The Prime Minister's first condition was that `the use of the word "Macedonia" be settled in a way that does not cause further tension with Greece'.

In fact, the use of the word `Macedonia' is by no means settled. Mr Peacock noted that the Greek Prime Minister, Mr Papandreou, had reiterated on 18 January that Greece would not accept the inclusion of `Macedonia' or any derivative in the `neighbouring state's name'.

Formal diplomatic use of this name by Australia could cause further tension with Greece, Mr Peacock said. This was clearly demonstrated by Greek Foreign Minister Venizelos' sharply negative reaction on 10 February to the US decision to recognise `The Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia'.

Mr Peacock considers, despite the Government's protestations to the contrary, that even temporary use of the word `Macedonia' is necessarily presumptive of the outcome of any negotiations on the issue between Athens and Skopje.

Nor has Mr Keating's second condition been met. The Greek Government's approach to the issue has been more constructive in recent weeks, Mr Peacock said. But the fact is that when speaking in the Greek Parliament on 24 January, Greek Prime Minister Papandreou made it quite clear that Greece's concerns have not yet been fully met and for this reason, Athens has not yet resumed UN sponsored talks with Skopje.
Melbourne, 15 February 1994

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Resources. Late last year the former Minister for Resources, Michael Lee, granted seven hardwood woodchip export licences, in violation of the government's moratorium policy on the logging of high conservation forests. Given the high level of concern about the conversion of our old growth forests and wilderness areas into low value woodchips, expressed by the Democrats and the environment movement generally, will the minister table copies of the 1994 woodchip export licences, and if not, why not? If the minister is not prepared to table these licences for reasons of commercial-in-confidence, will the minister list the criteria by which he judges whether material is commercial-in-confidence? Finally, how does he think the public interest is served by denying information to the public about the destruction of a public resource for private gain?

—I do not accept the statement contained in the last part of Senator Coulter's question. I did receive some advice from Senator Coulter that he was going to ask a question on this matter, but only half an hour ago. In the short time I have had to refer the matter to the Minister for Resources, Mr Beddall, I have been advised that many of these licence documents do contain commercial-in-confidence material and I have asked Mr Beddall to examine the documents to see how much of them are in that category. Having consulted further with him, I will provide Senator Coulter with whatever information I can in relation to his question and, in that respect, I will take that part of Senator Coulter's question on notice.

—Is the Minister for Health aware of claims by the President of the AMA that the government's private health insurance reform proposal is unfair? Does the AMA have its own proposal to reform the system? Does the AMA's view take into account all factors which have led to a problem for people with private insurance?

—As I understand it, the AMA is going to prepare a proposal; we just have not seen it yet. The reason we have not seen it yet, of course, is that when 284,000 individuals drop their private health insurance in one year, and those consumers do not believe they are getting value for money, the AMA cannot and will not face up to the problem of the out-of-pocket medical expenses paid to a minority of specialists.

PARA.TAB: For instance, 32.9 per cent of surgeons charge more than 30 per cent above the Medicare benefits schedule and consumers are forced to meet that from their own pockets. Dr Nelson's reported solution is an easy one: the taxpayer foots the bill. He believes there should be a major review of the Medicare benefits schedule to help eliminate out of pocket costs. I suppose that is because that would bring it into line with what those 30 per cent of doctors are charging. It would be a bit rich for the AMA to claim that now, given that it walked out of the process in 1985. A relative value study is currently proceeding but it walked out on the process in 1985. Obviously, I am not and could not be against highly skilled, highly trained doctors who provide services to Australians being well remunerated. I also have to say that the great majority of doctors—more than two-thirds—choose not to exploit their market power; but one third does. A minority of them exploit their position and do so shamelessly.

Professor Lawson and Mr Kevin Forde from the University of New South Wales released data today which proves what I have been saying. They reveal that in 1991-92, 42 specialists received more than $700,000 in Medicare benefits alone—apart from the compensation work and everything else. In that same year, Medicare paid more than $300,000 to 31.4 per cent of dermatologists, 22 per cent of ophthalmic surgeons, 22 per cent of ENT specialists, 25 per cent of cardiologists, and so the list goes on. Of course, those are the specialities where the gap of 30 per cent is most common. The top quarter of ophthalmologists earn around $597,000 a year every year. The top quarter of ear, nose and throat specialists earn $593,000 a year every year.

TALK.START.PARA: —Politics of envy.

—No, not the politics of envy; politics that say that taxpayers money should subsidise this situation even more. That is what those opposite agree with and what we do not agree with. I want to make it absolutely clear that, if any additional taxpayer funds are available for the health system, they will be spent on Medicare and not on propping up specialist incomes.

PARA.TAB: The fundamental point in my announcement that the AMA opposes is that this puts a brake on the outrageous out of pocket costs charged by some specialists. Dr Nelson's answer is that those doctors should simply inform their patients what they are going to charge. That has been AMA policy for a long time, but the problem is that certain doctors have ignored it time and time again and will continue to do so. Perhaps now is the time for the AMA to acknowledge that greed has been a major factor in killing private health insurance—the greed of a small minority of surgeons and specialists. They should learn that the quality of the doctor-patient relationship is about more than the untrammelled right to bill as they see fit.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. It follows the question asked of him by Senator Burns, who, I note with interest, asked it as a Queensland senator; I was surprised that it did not come from Victoria. I refer the minister to the Prime Minister's statement on 3 March 1992 in which he said `Australia will not proceed to recognition' of what was then known as the Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia until three basic pre-conditions were met. I ask the minister: why did he, on 15 February, announce that the Keating government had decided to recognise that republic, despite the fact that at least two of the government's basic three conditions had quite clearly not been met? I also ask whether he can understand the strong sense of betrayal felt by the Greek Australian community as a result of the actions of the Australian government?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —From the outset, the Australian government has understood the degree of emotion which exists in Greece and in the Greek community in Australia about this issue and, in particular, about those unacceptable aspects of the Skopje government's behaviour over recent years. In particular, I refer to the unacceptable appropriation of Macedonian cultural symbols—the Star of Vergina conspicuous among them. Also, we have always regarded it as quite appropriate that the name of the country be resolved in a way that satisfies the aspirations of both countries. There are relatively easily understood ways through that particular dilemma—for example, by the use of some hyphenated name such as Vardar-Macedonia, or the name Northern Macedonia, or something of that kind—which the international community has been pressing upon both parties, so far without much success.

PARA.TAB: I make it clear that there has been no resiling from the three conditions that were set. The first condition identified by Mr Keating was:

ANSWER.PARA: The use of the word `Macedonia' being settled in a way that does not cause further tension with Greece.

The situation is that while the name issue has, obviously, not been finally resolved, it has been satisfactorily settled for the time being by the international community, including Greece itself, accepting the temporary name `Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia', as an appropriate basis for the admission of that country into the United Nations. Of course, the rest of the international community has acted on that particular understanding.

PARA.TAB: As to the question of further tension associated with that, I discussed the issue directly with the Greek government when I was in Athens and I have made the judgment that a statement of this kind by us at this time in the context of the international recognition that has occurred, and using that temporary name, would not add further to the tensions with the Greek government in that respect. That was that particular criterion.

As to the question about Greece's concerns about its territorial claims or aspirations, the amendment to the FYROM constitution in July 1992, after Mr Keating's original statement which spelt out in constitutional terms that the country had no territorial pretensions towards any neighbouring states, together with a number of restatements since then by President Gligorov of FYROM's intentions in this respect, most recently on 10 February, together with the conclusions of the earlier Badinter commission that FYROM had no territorial aspirations, in my judgment, and that of Mr Keating and the government as a whole, represents a satisfaction of that second condition.

As to the third condition, the international community's concern about the protection of minorities being fully satisfied, the recognition action which has now been taken by so many European and indeed other countries right around the world—at the conclusion of this answer I will seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a list of the countries that have acted to recognise in this respect—has signified acceptance by all those countries, including us, of, again, the Badinter commission's findings that FYROM's constitutional guarantees on human rights and the rights of minorities are absolutely comparable with those applicable in the rest of Europe and do satisfy recognition standards.

I again repeat that this is a delicate and sensitive issue in which it has to be understood that there is right on both sides; certainly right in terms of the basic responses of the Greek government and community, but also on the part of the other government and those 75,000 people of Slavic or northern Macedonian or former Yugoslavian/Macedonian descent who have been denied access to consular services by this continuing stand-off. There is also the question that Australian foreign policy has to be conducted with credibility and consistency. We believe that all those objectives have been met. It was not an easy decision, but one that had to be made. I ask accordingly for the incorporation in Hansard both of the list of countries that have recognised and also the relevant statements by Prime Minister Papandreou.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. At the outset I agree with the minister that it is a delicate and sensitive issue. I follow that by asking: does he not agree that it was the Prime Minister's own laying down of the preconditions—preconditions which quite clearly have not been met—that is the cause of the problem, and did not Senator Evans realise before he made his statement that he would become the architect of the regrettable tensions now being experienced in the Greek and former Yugoslav communities in Australia?
—Another ethnic opportunism to jump on.

—I fully embrace what Senator Robert Ray has just said. It is vulgar, disgusting and demeaning for Senator Short and all the rest of his ilk to come up with these sorts of lines. You do not respond in a reasoned way to the reasoned arguments that I have articulated as to why recognition was a necessary course of action. You respond in an emotional and political way.

—I raise a point of order. I think we all understand that the standing orders clearly make it improper for any minister to reflect and cast the imputations that Senator Evans has on Senator Short. I thought we were about to get some maturity from an adult. All we have had is a boy's behaviour giving the lie to the Prime Minister's mouthings at the weekend about playing the man. I ask you, Mr President, to make Senator Evans play the ball.

—Order! This is a heated issue upon which heated views have been expressed on both sides. I do not see anything unparliamentary about what has been said so far, but I urge the minister to complete his answer.

—I responded in a quiet and reasoned way to the particular issues that have been raised about consistency with what the Prime Minister has previously said. There was no assault on the reasoning involved. It was just a matter of Senator Short getting up and saying manifestly that those conditions have not been satisfied. Might I say that is simply not good enough—whether it comes from Senator Short, Mr Peacock or Mr Kennett, or whether it comes from any other vulgar opportunist on the other side.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Resources. I refer to the minister's reply to a question from me on 2 February 1994 on woodchip export licences in which he claimed that the recent New South Wales bushfires `did more damage than years of sustained logging would have accomplished'. First, is he aware that the Resource Assessment Commission forest and timber inquiry, on page 165 of its 1992 final report, found assertions of this kind false and simplistic? Secondly, can he substantiate his remarks with scientific references? If so, what are these references?

—If any scientific evidence is available for Senator Chamarette, I will certainly obtain it for her. But I do not resile for one minute from the statement that I made. The bushfires in New South Wales did horrific damage to both the forest resource and the equally precious flora and fauna resource of New South Wales. If she wants evidence—she does not need scientific evidence—I suggest that she go and take a look for herself.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I would like to clarify my question to the minister. He made a statement that the bushfires did more damage—I am not disputing that irretrievable damage was done—than years of sustained logging would have accomplished. That implies a framework on the part of this government that needs to be substantiated with scientific and factual references. I ask the minister whether he is willing to retract his statement of 2 February if he is unable to provide that factual support?
—I understand the political rather than scientific point that Senator Chamarette is attempting to make, but it is becoming a little laboured at this stage.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. I refer to his answer in the Senate last Thursday when he claimed that the true debt owing by the Prime Minister's piggery group to Mr John Brown's company was the audited amount of $2.76 million rather than the $4.45 million originally revealed. Is it not a fact that the audited accounts from which he selectively quoted also showed that this audited figure was arrived at only after retrospectively reducing the existing debt by more than $1 million? What is the truth of the matter? Has the Prime Minister's company actually paid back $1.7 million to Mr Brown or has his old mate and very successful Labor lobbyist been so gracious as to write off more than one-third of the debt of the Prime Minister's company to him?

—I hope that Senator Baume has appreciated two strictures, the first of which is the extent to which in the past he has been utterly wrong every time he has sought to draw linkages of this kind between the Prime Minister's commercial involvement and questions of public interest or duty. As I have said, he has been wrong on three or four previous occasions in the past—and he will be just as wrong again. The second stricture he should bear in mind is that which the Prime Minister himself said publicly, that if you are going to continue to go down this particular path you have got to expect some retaliation in due course. You will get it.
—I raise a point of order, Mr President. I think that is a threat which you might address as well; but that is not the point. The point of order I take is that the minister would understand that—
—You poor wimp.

—It is not a question of `poor wimp'. The minister would understand that there is a very serious issue of conflict of interest involved here—a matter of indebtedness of the Prime Minister's company to a lobbyist. It is just about as serious as one could expect of a question—
—Rubbish.

—You might not think so, but the Australian people have a different view. It is just about as serious as one could expect of a question which is not at all personal in nature. This is an appropriate question which the minister should be obliged to answer if he is going to exercise the responsibility that the Leader of the Government in the Senate should exercise.
—I ask Senator Evans to come to the point.

—I made those points by way of preliminary emphasis because I have answered directly and explicitly the potential conflict point involved. The whole point here is that Mr Brown has no conceivable leverage—whatever the amount in question might be or how it might be calculated—over the company or its shareholders because any funds that might be dispensed to Mr Brown from this particular arrangement, which was entered into before the Prime Minister had anything to do with the company, is entirely at the company's discretion. It was in the nature of some sort of residual goodwill arrangement, contingent upon commercial success and at the discretion of the company directors concerned. If it is at the discretion of the company directors concerned, of which Mr Keating is not one, as to whether this amount is payable, what conceivable leverage could there be over Mr Keating or over the company?

PARA.TAB: The whole goose chase on which Senator Baume is embarked is a wild one because it is based on false and fanciful premises. That is what I said last week; that is what I will go on saying every time he asks his question. I do not have the details of the audited accounts in front of me and whatever particular background there might be to this or that figure. The basic point is that, whatever figure was audited in the accounts, the state of play is as I have described it—a maximum amount which is payable in the event that the directors so choose. It is not payable at request; it is not capable of being called in by Mr Brown or anyone else. As a result, it is not a loan in the normal sense and, as such, Senator Baume cannot even begin to get started on this bloody-handed exercise in muckraking that he is presently embarked upon.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. As the adjustments to this debt were made 18 months after Mr Keating became a half owner of this project, I ask: because of the potential for conflict of interest between the Prime Minister's private interests and his public duty, is the minister denying that the real debt is $4.45 million? If so, will the minister explain why the audited accounts from which he quoted made these retrospective provisions against this debt? If Mr Brown has not been paid this money nor forgiven the debt, is this reduction a book entry, with the missing $1.7 million being transferred into loans to related entities which increase to $19 million in the audited accounts? Why does the minister not come clean? How much is the Prime Minister's company still owing Mr Brown?

—I repeat: the question is based on a totally false premise. When one does not have something in the nature of a loan that is capable of being called in by the alleged lender in question, one does not have a situation where leverage of any kind is capable of being applied, and that is the basic point. Unless Senator Baume understands that, he will not understand anything about the nature of this arrangement. The honourable senator does understand it because he has made that point about the nature of this particular financial arrangement on a number of previous occasions. He is just engaged in a fishing, trawling expedition of the kind he engaged in with AQIS, of the kind he engaged in with FIRB—making exactly these kinds of allegations for week after week after week on end. It was proven at the end of the day that he had absolutely nothing but egg on his face, and that will be proven to be the case again.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Defence, and it relates to the challenges which the people of Cambodia face in rebuilding their war ravaged country, especially in disposing of a large number of landmines. Can the minister outline to the Senate whether assistance is being provided by the Australian Defence Force to help the Cambodian government with mine clearance and with the establishment of an effective national defence force?

—As a government and a country we made the decision some time ago to contribute $1 million this financial year through AIDAB to support the Cambodian mine action centre. There are four Australian defence personnel involved at this stage. We also made a concurrent decision to look at involving Cambodia in the defence cooperation program—a program of approximately $70 million a year spread over a number of countries.

PARA.TAB: We intend next financial year to include Cambodia in that program in order to help it build a competent professional defence force. As part of those discussions that will take place with the government of Cambodia later this financial year, we will give further consideration to what additional support we can offer that government in its efforts to clear an estimated eight million to 10 million landmines in Cambodia.

A lot of attention has been given in Cambodia to economic development, but I would argue that that is only possible as long as a thorough and extensive landmine clearance program goes ahead, because there can be no progress in the rest of Cambodia while large numbers of mines are sitting around. So, outside our existing support arrangements, we will discuss with the Cambodian government whether we can do more in assisting it to get rid of what is the greatest hazard to its future development.

—To the best of my knowledge, no—
—No to what?

—No. The answer to the first part of the question is no, I do not know the detail of who has been consulted in the process. I am familiar with the detail of the second part of Senator Kernot's question, which relates to the social justice package in that—
—I am not asking about that.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Is the land fund expected to be part of this budget? If it is, would it not be at a certain stage of its processes by now?

—I refer the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy to the schedule for tobacco that has been submitted to the GATT Uruguay Round for an import quota of 11,184,000 kilograms—a level which represents 70 to 80 per cent of Australia's consumption, because it is based on the very high levels of 1986 and 1988 and does not reflect today's lower consumption levels. As both the manufacturers and the growers admit, the quota is too high and a mistake. What is the government prepared to do to restructure the industry when, as a consequence of the high schedule, the Australian tobacco growing industry will lose another 30 per cent of its production to imports, and half of its growers? By contrast, the US has introduced a local content rule of 75 per cent, while Australia is removing its mixing regulations altogether.

—I am aware of the concern raised by Senator Boswell in respect of both growers and manufacturers about Australia's commitments in the Uruguay Round and, in particular, the commitment to convert the local leaf content scheme to tariff only protection when the Uruguay Round is implemented, probably in early 1995. The government is also aware that the tobacco industry is currently subject to an Industry Commission inquiry to bring forward recommendations to the government on the future regime for tobacco production in Australia. That is a major inquiry being conducted into the industry by the Industry Commission. I am sure Senator Boswell is aware of it.

PARA.TAB: The commission is to report to the government on this matter by the middle of the year at which time the government, having considered that report, will make decisions on the future arrangements for the tobacco industry in respect of our commitments under GATT. There have been consultations with the Australian tobacco industry over the period of the GATT negotiations and these consultations with the tobacco industry will continue.

The industry's concerns have been registered and understood by the government and I am confident that a solution can be found after the Industry Commission reports on the current examination that it is making of the industry, which will probably be about the middle of the year.
I am confident that a solution can be found which will ensure that Australia's Uruguay Round obligations are met and which will also provide a continuing market for Australian processed tobacco.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. I refer to the appalling massacre of innocent Palestinians in prayer at Hebron last Friday, something which has deeply shocked Australians and the entire international community. Given that the casualties far exceed those caused by any other single act of violence in the territories for a quarter of a century, in the minister's view could this tragedy have the effect of undermining the peace process in the Middle East? In the assessment of the Australian government, what is an appropriate response?

—As I have already said publicly over the weekend, the Australian government is deeply shocked and saddened by the senseless killing and wounding of innocent Palestinians who were at prayer, and we do extend our very profound sympathy to all those bereaved or wounded.

PARA.TAB: We have condemned without reservation this act of utter, appalling insanity, aimed at killing innocent Arab people and with the potential effect of destroying the whole peace process. Tragic though the bloodshed is, it would be an even greater tragedy if the peace which has so long eluded Israelis and Palestinians were to be jeopardised in this way by one man's hatred.

At this time of heightened emotion, it is of the utmost importance that Israelis and Palestinians alike exercise restraint so that extremists of all kinds are not further encouraged. We certainly welcome the unqualified condemnation of this brutal act by Israel's Prime Minister and his government.

We believe, however, that it is the responsibility of Israel, as the occupying power, to do all it can to prevent the recurrence of such acts. We welcome Israel's decision to establish an inquiry into the massacre and reports that Israel will move to disarm the most violent of the Jewish settlers and arrest their leaders. We also very warmly welcome moves to set free up to 1,000 Palestinian detainees.

It is doubtful, however, that these moves will in themselves be sufficient to restart negotiations immediately, although it is reassuring that both sides have accepted President Clinton's invitation to attend continuous negotiations in Washington. This means that the Washington talks, when they begin, will subsume technical negotiations which have until now been proceeding separately in Washington, Paris and Egypt.

The PLO has demanded, among other things, that Israel disarm all settlers in the territories, that Israel accept the presence of international peacekeepers in the occupied territories and that the issue of settlements in the territories be placed on the negotiating agenda immediately. We understand as to the question of international peacekeepers that this may be considered by the Security Council, but we also know that the United States as well as, of course, Israel itself have serious reservations about this idea. It is not yet clear how the further disarming of settlers or the wider question of settlements will be addressed in these negotiations.

The declaration of principles that was signed last September provides that settlements are to be discussed as part of the permanent status talks scheduled to begin no later than the beginning of the third year after the completion of Israel's withdrawal from Gaza and Jericho. But might I say in that respect that we do feel there is a strong onus on Israel to ensure that its citizens do not commit provocative acts which could further imperil the peace process and to act within the limit of its power and capacity to ensure that that happens.

It is certainly my strong hope—I am sure it is one that all honourable senators here will share—that this latest outrage may galvanise the two sides' negotiators to take decisive steps toward finalising an agreement on Israel's withdrawal from Gaza and Jericho. Without that there is very real danger of the whole peace process losing its momentum and in fact going rapidly backwards.

Might I just say very quickly on a related matter that the government also unequivocally condemns the latest outrage in Lebanon in which Christian worshippers were killed by a bomb blast. We do not yet have full details of this atrocity, but obviously we hope that the perpetrators will be brought quickly to account and that this does not signal the resumption of a new cycle of violence in that benighted country.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Family Services. Why has the minister extended the one-year date by which community based child-care centres must register with the national child-care accreditation system to qualify for fee relief? Is it a fact that the majority of child-care centres and parents share the concerns raised by the coalition and that they are having great difficulty in interpreting the 52 principles?

—What is clear to this point is that in large part the child-care community is not having difficulty with what accreditation is about at all. From the figures I had last week, of the 2,800-plus child-care centres eligible to register—I am not sure of the exact figures—well over 1,000 centres had registered. In the not quite two months to this point, that is very heartening indeed. The breakdown of those figures is not at the front of my brain; I cannot be sure of the proportion. When I last looked at it, between 35 and 40 per cent of those centres were private child-care centres.

PARA.TAB: The figures are a little confused because the last figures I saw showed that 111 centres were private centres, new centres, about to become operative as child-care centres and very keen to become part of the accreditation process. As the centres have made quite clear, they know that their accreditation will be a very good recommendation to the potential users of those centres. They will be able to say, `We are an accredited child-care centre', and they know the message that that is sending to the community.

The evidence from the figures coming in at this stage is very heartening and encouraging indeed, as is the number of requests from centres for information about the accreditation process. I have written to all centres to make it clear that the registration and accreditation process would not have caused any confusion or any possible cutting off of child-care assistance until 1 July 1995. I wanted centres to know that they have my assurance that I am interested in getting the accreditation process up and running. Indeed, I am interested in doing away with the confusion and the division in the community about this, and I wanted to give the centres that kind of clarification so that they could now, if they had any reservations at all, have that assurance and proceed to the accreditation process.
I think we can be very heartened. The figures so far indicate that centres are very keen for further information, and the numbers registering to this point would be very good evidence of that.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Regional Development. Is the minister aware of the recent announcement by the world's largest manufacturer of undersea pipes to establish a manufacturing site in Australia? Could the minister outline this initiative and, in particular, what this might mean for Fremantle and Western Australia?

—Australia is increasingly becoming a site for investment by very large international corporations. On 2 February, Coflexip SA, the Paris based supplier of 90 per cent of the world's demand for flexible pipe for undersea oil and gas wells, made an in-principle decision to establish a new factory in Fremantle. This will increase Coflexip's global production by about 25 per cent.

PARA.TAB: Coflexip's decision to locate this plant in Australia shows its confidence in Australia as a base from which to supply export markets in the burgeoning Asia and Pacific region. It shows Australia as a country winning on the world stage as a source of advanced manufacturing technologies. It is also clear evidence of our advantages across a number of areas against very strong regional competition. To gain this new facility, Australia had to beat a determined counter offer from Singapore.

The decision reflects a concerted effort on the part of several Commonwealth agencies—Austrade, the investment promotion unit within Treasury and my department—to consult closely with Coflexip in its assessment of Australia as a location for the new facility. These discussions began in Paris last year and extended to several meetings between the Commonwealth government involving a number of ministers—the former Treasurer Mr Dawkins, Mr Frank Walker, my predecessor Mr Alan Griffiths, myself and the company. The WA government has also provided substantial assistance to ensure that this project is sited in Fremantle.

The facility is a multimillion dollar project—$80 million, in fact—and local manufacturers will be supplying a substantial proportion of the capital equipment for it. Benefits from this new facility include substantial input replacement benefits of $44 million per annum, annual exports to the Asia-Pacific region of $30 million per annum, and up to 250 direct new jobs for the Fremantle region, before we calculate the multiplier effects. Having the world's major player in this industry established in Fremantle will greatly increase the demand for local supply of pipes, iron and steel, plastics and general services.

As I said, this is a vote of confidence in Australia and in Fremantle by this giant international corporation, which will bring a huge number of new jobs to that centre. In choosing its location, it has done so strategically and well because of the increasing demand there will be for its products on the North West Shelf and developments in near Asia.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. I also refer to the horrific massacre in Hebron, at prayers last Friday morning, a massacre which we absolutely condemn. I accept the minister's answer to Senator Loosely's question with regard to the peace process and what we can do to stabilise it but I ask further: what is the Australian government now doing to strengthen the peace process that has been taking place over recent months? What new adjustments can be made to signal our renewed commitment to the peace process? Frankly, what has the Australian government, in concert with the international community, done in the last three days along these lines?

—We have recognised from the outset that we cannot possibly play any kind of a useful party principal role in the resolution of this particular conflict. I guess our role, essentially, has been twofold. First, it is to press upon both sides—the Israelis and their supporters on the one hand, and the Palestinians and their supporters on the other—how crucial we think it is that there be movement down the track mapped out in the declaration of principles. We have given our political support and encouragement to that at every available opportunity through bilateral discussions and our performance in the UN and other multilateral forums.

PARA.TAB: The second thing we can do is participate more directly in the multilateral track of the peace process, which we have been doing through our participation in two groups in particular. One is the water resources group, that being a crucial economic issue which has to be sorted out to everyone's comfort if the longer term peace and stability of the region are to be assured. We have a tremendous amount of expertise in that area which we have made available. My understanding is that it has been appreciated.

The other area in the multilateral track is the arms control and regional security discussions, a much more delicate and difficult area for obvious reasons. Australia has expertise to offer, not least because of our involvement in the chemical weapons treaty and, more particularly in a regional context, the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone and the other initiatives that we have taken in this respect in our own South-East Asian and larger Asia-Pacific regions.

We have indicated a willingness to participate constructively and helpfully, so long as we are welcome, in that particular process. In fact, we have reiterated that in discussions in the last few days. I cannot pretend that we have added anything more specific than that in the last two or three days in particular, other than very strong statements, and I hope some specific and constructive ones, about the nature of the responsibilities that in particular need to be exercised by the government of Israel in its capacity as the government in charge of the Occupied Territories. It is not made in any spirit of unhelpful criticism but rather as an indication that the international community would be very supportive indeed if it is prepared to go the extra mile in that respect.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Because the perpetrator of this mass murder happens to have been born in the United States, is there an international element to the investigation and prosecution of this terrible murder?

—Not that I am aware. I simply do not know whether he continues to be a United States citizen and just an Israeli resident or whether there is an international character about it. But in any event, with a criminal act of this kind what is involved is the criminal law and practice of the state where the actions took place, and I would not envisage any larger investigation being necessary.

PARA.TAB: I suppose when a massacre occurs on this scale there is an element of almost a war crime character about it, but I do not think anyone has seriously suggested that it would be helpful to go down this particular path. The important thing is that the Israeli government react as it has, with unequivocal condemnation and by setting in train an appropriate inquiry and appropriate policy steps to deal with the unresolved question of settlers in the region and the whole question of the future course of the peace negotiations. Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: National Health and Medical Research Council: Funding

TALK.START.PARA: —In response to a question asked by Senator Harradine on 24 February, I gave an undertaking to provide further information concerning funding for the National Health and Medical Research Council. In relation to the illustration provided by the honourable senator, research involving the use of foetal tissue is covered by specific guidelines issued by the National Health and Medical Research Council. These guidelines require that the research is conducted only in institutions that have a properly constituted ethics committee and only according to written protocols approved by the ethics committees of all institutions involved.

PARA.TAB: The guidelines also require that the decision regarding abortion is kept quite separate from the decision to carry out the research. Furthermore, the specific consent of the mother and, whenever practicable, of the father, should be obtained where tissues or cells are to be transplanted.

The honourable senator in his question asked whether the National Health and Medical Research Council, as a science based body, was appropriate to determine whether such experiments and other research involving ethics issues should proceed. As I am sure he would remember, this was the subject of detailed consideration by the Senate in 1992 when the bill establishing the National Health and Medical Research Council as a statutory authority was debated.

In its consideration of the matter, the Senate sought to achieve an appropriate balance between having an ethics body that is close enough to the National Health and Medical Research Council to be aware of current issues in the health sphere, including research, and having appropriate independence to perform its role effectively.

The NHMRC act provides for ethics guidelines to be developed by the Australian Health Ethics Committee through a process of public consultation and to be issued without variation by the National Health and Medical Research Council. All medical research conducted in institutions receiving funding from the National Health and Medical Research Council is subject to these guidelines.

The NHMRC act also specifies the constitution of the Health Ethics Committee. The Senate, in considering this aspect, concluded that having the Australian Health Ethics Committee as a principal committee of the National Health and Medical Research Council would enable deliberations to be relevant and timely with regard to developments in research, whilst at the same time providing an appropriate degree of independence. I hope to be in a position to announce the membership of the new Australian Health Ethics Committee shortly.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 9 February I tabled a response to a question from Senator Panizza concerning the impact of the embargo placed by Iraq on Australian wheat pools. I have been advised that there was an error in the exchange rates that we used in converting the United States dollar amounts to Australian dollars. The US dollar figures given in the answer were correct; the error was a mathematical one that occurred in the conversion to Australian dollars.

PARA.TAB: It has also come to light that the AWB share of the risk was higher for some contracts, so the AWB's exposure is $US99 million and not $US97 million as previously advised. Of course, the final Australian dollar equivalent of that will depend on the exchange rate at the time of repayment as the contractual arrangement is for US dollars. I seek leave of the Senate to incorporate in Hansard the answer with the correct figures.
Leave granted.
The answer read as follows—

ANSWER.PARA: Australia is owed US$482 million for wheat sold to Iraq prior to the imposition of United Nations trade sanctions in 1990. The Australian Wheat Board has already been reimbursed US$382 million under their Export Finance and Insurance Corporation (EFIC) national interest insurance policy. Converted to Australian dollars at the exchange rates prevailing at the times the reimbursements on individual contracts were made, this amounted to $A496 million.

This sharing of the risk, 80% Commonwealth and 20% AWB, and in some cases 70% Commonwealth and 30% AWB reflects the contractual agreements reached for the provision for insurance cover for these sales under the national interest facility.

The AWB has an exposure to Iraqi debt of US$99 million relating to equity in the 1987/88, 1988/89 and the 1989/90 wheat pools. None of this debt has been written off. At an exchange rate of $A1 to US$0.72 this exposure amounts to $A138 million.
Iraq has undertaken to repay all of this debt as soon as it is able to do so. Its ability to repay will depend on when the United Nations decides to lift its sanctions on Iraq.

In addition, the government has paid the grains industry $33 million to cover losses on sales of wheat, rice and yellow split peas contracted prior to the imposition of the United Nations trade sanctions on Iraq (in August 1990), and associated costs in re-selling those commodities to alternative markets.

The equity relating to Iraqi debt in the 1987/88 (US$4 million) and 1988/89 (US$42 million) pools was transferred to the 1990/91 pool at a nominal amount to allow the closure of these pools. The equity relating to Iraqi debt was placed in a separate account. The AWB has advised growers that a record of their entitlements in these pools will be maintained for at least 3 years and any payments from Iraq received during that time will be paid to the growers concerned.

Australian growers are carrying the balance of their exposure to Iraqi debt as equity in the 1989/90 pool worth some US$53 million. The Australian Wheat Board is currently considering the options available to close this pool.

ANSWER.PARA: 28 February 1994
JUDICIAL INQUIRY INTO ASIS

I announced in the Senate on 23 February that the Government had decided in principle to set up a judicial inquiry into the operation and management of the Australian Secret Intelligence Service (ASIS). I confirm today the decision of the Government to establish such a Judicial Inquiry. The Inquiry will have appropriate investigative powers and witnesses will have appropriate protection.

The Inquiry will be headed by a distinguished former judge, the Hon Gordon J Samuels AC QC, formerly of the New South Wales Supreme Court and Court of Appeal (1972-92); former President of the Security Appeals Tribunal (1980-90); Chancellor of the University of New South Wales; and Chairman of the NSW Law Reform Commission.

To assist Mr Samuels specifically with organisation and management issues, Mr Michael Codd AC, former Secretary of the Department of Prime Minister and Cabinet, will be appointed as Commissioner Assisting. Counsel Assisting will be Mr Chris Maxwell of the Melbourne Bar.
The Inquiry has been asked to report if possible by 30 September 1994, and in any case no later than 31 December 1994.
The Inquiry will have as its terms of reference:
(a) to inquire into the effectiveness and suitability of existing arrangements for:
(i) the control and accountability of the Service;
(ii) the organisation and management of the Service;
(iii) the protection of the Service's intelligence sources and methods;
(iv) the resolution of grievances and complaints relating to the Service; and
(b) to consider whether any changes in existing arrangements are required or desirable.

It is not proposed that the Inquiry address the functional role and priorities of ASIS: these issues were exhaustively addressed, in relation to both ASIS and the intelligence community as a whole, by the Government in 1992. Any questions concerning the Service's relations with other agencies and departments can be dealt with under one or other of the above-stated terms of reference.

Given the role of ASIS and the nature of its work, the Inquiry will have the power to hold hearings in camera, and it is expected that most of the Inquiry will be conducted on this basis. Submissions will be sought from interested parties.

The Government is concerned that purported revelations by former ASIS officers have the potential to compromise national security. It is the Government's firm expectation that now that this Inquiry has been established, they will make known their concerns about the organisation and management of ASIS to the Inquiry and that further public comment by former ASIS officers will cease. If this does not prove to be the case, the Government will, where necessary, take firm and prompt action in the interests of national security.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to say a couple of things about the inquiry. It will be headed by a very distinguished and experienced former judge, the Hon. Gordon J. Samuels AC QC, formerly of the New South Wales Supreme Court and Court of Appeal, former President for 10 years of the Security Appeals Tribunal, currently Chancellor of the University of New South Wales and Chairman of the New South Wales Law Reform Commission. To assist Mr Samuels specifically with organisation and management issues, Mr Michael Codd AC, former Secretary to the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet, will be appointed as commissioner assisting.

PARA.TAB: The inquiry will have appropriate investigative and protective powers. Its terms of reference will be essentially those which I have previously outlined and deal with: the control and accountability of the service, its organisation and management; the protection of its intelligence sources and methods; and the resolution of grievances and complaints relating to the service.Might I say finally that it is not proposed that the inquiry address the functional role and priorities of ASIS. These issues were exhaustively addressed in relation to both ASIS and the intelligence community as a whole by the government in 1992.

—Yes, once upon a time. In fact, the Inspector-General has referred to improper ways of investigating grievances of the staff of ASIS, and found they have been dealt with in ways that have not respected the principles of natural justice. That does not seem to concern the minister, but certainly concerns this side of the chamber.

The wider concern just mentioned is that if these complaints are being demonstrated to be soundly based through the work of the Inspector-General in relation to staff grievances, one can only suspect perhaps there may be some truth in some of the other allegations concerning operational matters. As a result of the comments that have been made the government has felt that it should set up an inquiry of this nature under the Hon. Gordon Samuels. To that extent these statements have already been vindicated. PARA.TAB: As to the second last point that was made about the government's statement in relation to certain individuals who have been going public with their grievances about ASIS, the government has very serious and very onerous responsibilities in the protection of national security and the protection of the national interests in this respect. We will carry out those responsibilities with full consciousness of the gravity of the issues that are involved. It is most unfortunate that the opposition should choose to trivialise and to score points about something which is obviously an example of the government properly exercising its various serious responsibilities.

I turn quickly to some of the other points that were made in this scatter-gun collection of misstatements from Senator Hill. He said at the outset that in my responses to the Senate estimates committee I had clearly intimated that if an inquiry were to be held it would address the question of the role, the functions and the priorities of the service. I said absolutely nothing of the kind. I challenge Senator Hill to find any explicit language in the estimates committee hearing to that effect.

I did say that, given the postwar environment, the new priorities, the new kinds of roles, the newly configured responsibilities of ASIS and the other intelligence organisations, and the additional funding that had been made available to the organisation over the last two years, there was certainly a case for looking closely at its organisation and management. That is something that I had been giving consideration to over the last few weeks.

A second point I was making in the estimates committee hearing, and I make again, is that in the post-Cold War environment, where the atmospherics have changed and the ground rules have changed in many ways, there is certainly a case for looking afresh at questions of control and accountability so far as these secret organisations are concerned and in particular, for example, looking at the question of whether or not their role might not be better governed by statute than by some form of executive direction. That is clearly one of the issues that will be addressed by the inquiry.

A further consideration flowing from the end of the Cold War and the change in the psychological climate that governed security matters in relation to that is that it is appropriate, again as I said at the estimates committee, to look again at the protective mechanisms that apply in relation to these organisations and, in particular, for example, the voluntary restraint arrangements through D notices. SPEECH.PARA: Senator Richardson is having a bit of a stoush with the AMA at the moment. I can understand the political context of that. It is the honourable senator's right and, in fact, his duty to do so when he sees fit, but selective quoting of documents is not honesty.

To achieve any sort of income under the health system, it is necessary to work hard. I know of one eye specialists who actually sees patients on Sunday mornings. He is an absolute workaholic. SPEECH.PARA: I remind the Senate that I asked two questions last week, the first of Senator Gareth Evans and the second of Senator Richardson representing the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories. PARA.TAB: The lie of the first question was this: Australia, in recent years, has increasingly thrown in its lot with Asian countries in the belief that Asia's economic development will be rapid and that somehow, by hooking our future to Asia, we can produce enormous economic and social benefits for this country.

He said that he had not seen those reports but he asserted in a facile way that economic growth in Asia would lead to the ability of Asian countries to spend more on the environment and so to clean up their environment; that there was nothing inconsistent between the declining environmental standards in Asia and an increase in economic wellbeing and therefore it was desirable for Australians to continue to link our future with that of Asia.

On Wednesday, I asked Senator Richardson, representing the minister for the environment, a question relating to stormwater and sewage. That was the point that Senator Richardson picked up today. The point was this: taking the one example of sewage and stormwater, there is abundant evidence that Australia needs to spend not millions of dollars, as Senator Richardson said today, but tens of billions of dollars to clean up problems all round this country, particularly—but not only—in relation to capital cities.

For example, the whole of the Murray-Darling Basin is very severely polluted. Blue-green algae has broken out again in the lower reaches of the Murray and people down there cannot drink the water and cannot use it for their cattle. Yet Australia, by any standards, is a rich country. The question I asked Senator Evans was: why is it that a rich country cannot find the money to clean up its environment? The point is that Senator Evans was totally wrong in his answer.

It is not good enough to say we become more able to spend more on cleaning up the environment as we become richer, because part of the process of becoming richer is the damaging of our environment. Australia as a rich country is one of the worst polluters in terms of greenhouse gas emissions. It has been one of the worst polluters in terms of ozone depleting gases. It is certainly very bad when it comes to its inability to properly deal with toxic wastes through sewage and stormwater, not least in Sydney, which was the example that Senator Richardson picked up today. The original question still stands and remains unanswered.

I voice again the very great concern that I have that this country is linking its future more and more strongly with Asia, where country after country is in severe environmental decline. The Chao Phraya River, which goes through Bangkok, is one of the most polluted rivers in the world. The Japanese have deliberately located a great deal of their polluting industry into Bangkok. The air in Bangkok is almost unbreathable, yet we are linking our future with those countries.I raise this warning that I think it is very unwise for us to do so.

These countries will not be able to spend more on cleaning up the environment as they become richer. It is more likely that they will not become richer. We should be pursuing a policy of much greater independence and spending more of our money looking after our own environment.
