SPEECH.PARA: I believe very strongly that Senator Gareth Evans today gave a grossly misleading presentation of the background to the government's betrayal of the Greek-Australian community over the manner of its recognition of the Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia. I would like to fill in a few facts that Senator Evans omitted to mention.

PARA.TAB: The first one is that this issue really goes back to the statement by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) on 3 March 1992, when he laid down three preconditions that the government said needed to be met before Australia would proceed to recognition of the Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia. Those three issues were, firstly, that the use of the word `Macedonia' had to be settled in a way that did not cause further tension with Greece; secondly, that Greece's concerns about possible territorial claims or aspirations needed to be fully met; and, thirdly, that the international community's concern about the protection of minorities needed to be fully satisfied. In his statement and as background, he said:

SPEECH.PARA: From the point of view of Greece, and the Greek community in Australia, the question of the recognition of the Yugoslavian republic known as Macedonia creates a number of problems which do not exist in relation to other present or former Yugoslavian republics.
He concluded his statement by saying:
Australia is firmly of the view that the recognition issue should be determined in a way which avoids creating new tensions in a region already undergoing such rapid change.

All of those points, of course, were ones that were fully supported by the opposition. But then on 15 February this year—that is, two years later—Senator Evans made the statement which has caused the present regrettable tensions within some of the communities in Australia. He announced:
Australia has decided to recognise as an independent state, and to commence discussions on diplomatic relations with, the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia.

Amongst other things he said in his statement was that he believed that in the light of the course of events since the Prime Minister's statement of March 1992, the three conditions that he mentioned had now been met. On that same day, in response to Senator Evans's statement, the shadow foreign minister, Mr Peacock, put out a statement which Senator Evans quoted from very selectively today. He omitted to read some things from Mr Peacock's statement. The press release stated:
But Mr Peacock said the Government's approach . . . was nevertheless flawed.
It also said:
. . . the Government has effectively broken the Prime Minister's undertaking not to proceed to recognition until basic outstanding questions are resolved.
In it, Mr Peacock said, rightly:
The Prime Minister's first condition was that "the use of the word "Macedonia" be settled in a way that does not cause further tension with Greece.
In fact, the use of the word "Macedonia" is by no means settled.

Mr Peacock noted that the Greek Prime Minister, Mr Papandreou, had reiterated on 18 January that Greece would not accept the inclusion of the name Macedonia or any derivative in that of the neighbouring states. Mr Peacock also pointed out that, when speaking in the Greek parliament on 24 January, Prime Minister Papandreou had made it quite clear that Greece's concerns had not yet been fully met—that is, in relation to the second condition—and, for this reason, Athens had not yet resumed UN-sponsored talks with Skopje. None of those points was made today by Senator Evans and, therefore, his response was extremely misleading.

PARA.TAB: The fact is that at yesterday's rally in Melbourne several members of parliament from Senator Evans's own party were there. Theo Theophanous was there. Demetri Dollis was there. I give them credit for being there. SPEECH.PARA: The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Collins) fobbed off my request that he substantiate his 2 February comments, as recorded in Hansard, by labelling the thrust of my questions as political. If there is anything political about them, it is the political way in which this government approaches the important issue of the destruction of high conservation value forests to service the woodchip and activated carbon or charcoal export industry.

PARA.TAB: I must admit that I expected a more good humoured response, as is more usual from Senator Collins—I appreciate that the minister may have been off guard because I gave him no forewarning of my question. There appears to be a longstanding practice or expectation of forewarning. I understand the difficulty of being kept informed across the broad range of issues in the minister's own portfolio, as well those in the portfolio of the minister whom he represents in this place. However, the minister is meant to know because he represents the Minister for Resources (Mr Beddall). This is a key area. There is little point in having ministers representing ministers in the other place if they are not, prior to question time, fully acquainted with major areas of government policy.

Finally, I believe that while it may not be his own portfolio area, the minister's own words are under question. I request that he be more careful to make statements, whether political or otherwise, that are based on fact rather than ill informed throwaway lines. The reality is that this government has demonstrated a lack of political will to implement the moratorium clause of its national forest policy. Those members of the community who are aware of this failure are deeply concerned about the future of Australia's forests. Those who are ignorant of this would be appalled at the rate at which Australia's high conservation value forests are disappearing.

It adds nothing whatsoever to the debate for a minister, who is representing the Minister for Resources, to expose the ignorance that may well be regarded as underlying some of the policies of this government in relation to the granting of woodchip export licences and the failure to protect Australia's high conservation value native forests in a suitable way—a way that does not have appalling implications for the future of forestry and this country.

The Greens have no objections whatsoever to sustainable logging practices that occur on plantations. But for the minister to have replied again—and he failed to substantiate his statement—that forest fires did more damage than the years of sustainable logging, implies a repetition of inaccurate and misleading information.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans), to a question without notice asked by Senator Baume this day, relating to the Prime Minister's investment in a piggery.

SPEECH.PARA: The Senate will be aware of the fact that Senator Gareth Evans is between a rock and a hard place on this matter. Of course, this may explain why his uncharacteristic rudeness and unusual personal abuse of me should have taken place. The fact is, of course, that if Senator Evans admits that there is still a debt of $4.45 million owing by the company of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) to Mr John Brown's company, he then admits that he has been misleading this chamber by saying that the real debt is $2.76 million remaining in the audited accounts.

PARA.TAB: Of course, if he sticks by his present version, which is that the true debt owing to Mr Brown is only $2.76 million, he has to explain what happened to the remaining $1.7 million. Was it magically hidden in the accounts in a book transfer, in which case why are the Prime Minister's companies—and why is Senator Evans—trying to pretend that a debt of $4.45 million is in fact only a debt of $2.76 million; a debt from the Prime Minister's half-owned company to Mr Brown, a former colleague, who is a very effective lobbyist and who is, of course, on some governmental bodies?

If Senator Evans continues to assert that it is only $2.76 million, then he has to assure this chamber that $1.7 million has not in fact been paid since the Prime Minister acquired his half interest. He has to assure this chamber that it has not been paid or has not been forgiven by Mr Brown since the Prime Minister became a half owner of this company while the Treasurer in May 1991. If he does not, if he cannot assure us of that, he clearly faces this magnificent conflict: he says there is no leverage because it does not have to be paid. If it has been paid—if that is the explanation and reason for the reduction from $4.45 million, which the accounts first revealed as at 30 June 1991, well after the Prime Minister acquired his interest—then Senator Evans's special submission that this loan has no leverage because it does not have to be paid until the company has earned a profit, and at the discretion of the directors, is self-evident bunkum.

Clearly Senator Evans is in a very difficult situation. Does he admit that Mr Brown's company is owed $4.45 million—which any sensible reading of the accounts clearly indicates—or does he stick to the fiction that all that is owed is the $2.76 million? By the way, whatever the amount is there is still a potential for conflict of interest because it is still a debt, whether it is subordinated or not. It still has to be paid one way or another if the company earns a profit.

I advise Senator Evans to go away and have a look at the accounts. He said that he did not have the accounts with him. I do, and these accounts clearly show, for Senator Evans's information, that the amount outstanding to Mr Brown and his company has been written down. There has been an allocation made against it in the current accounts. A total of more than $1 million has been written off this debt, presumably, I would suggest, by being transferred to, and submerged in, the huge volume of inter-company debt—$19 million. This debt has been transferred out of the clear debt to John Brown and hidden in this debt to related bodies.

It seems to me extraordinary that any government, any person or any company should go to these extremes to hide the level of indebtedness of the Prime Minister's company to a government lobbyist, Mr John Brown. Why on earth does Senator Evans not come clean? Why does he not admit what the facts are? It took us ages, months and months, to get him to admit that there was a $2.76 million debt, let alone the real debt of $4.45 million. What has this government got to hide? Why does it keep smearing me every time I reveal the facts in the ASC returns? It is on that basis that I keep asking these questions.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I table a revised explanatory memorandum and move:

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The speech read as follows—
The Housing Assistance Amendment Bill 1993 amends subsection 7(3A) and section 15 of the Housing Assistance Act 1989.

SPEECH.PARA: Under this act the States are provided with financial assistance by the Commonwealth to deliver housing assistance for rental housing and home purchase in accordance with the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement. That Agreement, commonly referred to as the CSHA, is Schedule 1 to the act.

In amending subsection 7(3A) of this act, the bill sets out revised appropriations made under the act for the years 1993 to 1996. This will give effect to a number of Government decisions announced in the 1993-94 Budget.

The revisions arise from a rephasing of $25 million originally brought forward to 1993-94 from out-years for the purposes of employment generation and of $10 million for the Community Housing Program which was originally to be available for payment in 1993-94. In addition, there has been a small one-off adjustment to new 1993-94 funds for the Crisis Accommodation Program.
Ensuring that Australians have access to affordable and appropriate housing remains a key priority for the Federal Government in 1993-94.

The amendment to appropriations proposed in this bill is consistent with the Government's housing priorities. It continues the Government's commitment to providing long term financial assistance for the provision of public housing, funding for the provision of the new Community Housing Program (CHP), and continuing support for the Crisis Accommodation Program.

In addition to the $1042.39 million to be appropriated in 1993-94 under the terms of the bill, the 1989 act also allows for unpaid Commonwealth funds to be carried forward from 1992-93. The Minister for Housing, Local Government and Human Services has determined that a total of $82.3 million will be carried forward under this provision, resulting in total Commonwealth funds available under the CSHA in 1993-94 of $1125 million.

As part of its 1992-1993 Budget initiatives, the Government announced that $100 million of CSHA funds earmarked for expenditure in later years would be available for expenditure on employment generation projects in 1992-93 and 1993-94.

These funds were to be made available for allocation to States which were able to demonstrate an ability to accelerate housing activity, particularly in areas of high unemployment. In 1992-93, $75 million in funds brought forward from later years was allocated to the States on this basis.

There can be no doubt that bringing forward these funds in 1992-93 was an important and successful initiative. It provided a significant boost to expenditure on construction and capital upgrading projects which were able to be implemented quickly. In addition, the projects funded in various States created additional employment while furthering the Government's strategic housing objectives in terms of social justice and urban consolidation.

On the basis of this success, the Government had no hesitation in approving the carry-over from 1992-93 of unpaid Commonwealth funds, totalling $22.3 million, to be available for payment to relevant States for employment generation purposes in 1993-94.
However, circumstances have changed since the decision to bring forward a further $25 million in Commonwealth funds to 1993-94 was made.
In 1992-93 housing sector activity was 15 per cent higher than it was in 1991-92. In addition, dwelling commencements in 1993-94 are expected to total about 168,000.

However, housing activity is presently predicted to be lower in 1994-95 than in 1991-92. The underlying level of demand has been forecast by the Indicative Planning Council as averaging 117,000 over the next five years. This is the product of a fall in demand due to a drop in immigration to Australia and the satisfaction of pent-up demand over the last year.

The carry-over of $82.3 million from 1992-93 into 1993-94 is also underpinning substantial capital and upgrading projects, which are currently planned or under way. It is estimated that this carry-over is supporting around 900 extra jobs in the construction industry. This employment boost is having flow-on effects to other economic sectors as well.
As a result, the need to allocate $25 million of funds, previously brought forward for expenditure in 1993-94, is not as pressing as it was when the decision was made more than a year ago.

For this reason, the Government has decided to rephase that $25 million so that an additional $12.5 million in CSHA funding will be available in untied funds in both 1994-95 and 1995-96. The $25 million intended for expenditure in 1993-94 is thus being fully restored over the following two years.
The new Community Housing Program has been designed to achieve an expansion of this sector and the Government has secured the enthusiastic support of non-government agencies to meet this challenge.

However, Federal Government funding for the CHP over the next three years has been revised to reflect likely expenditure patterns. Ten million dollars, originally earmarked for expenditure on the CHP in 1993-94, has been rephased so that an additional $5 million will be available for expenditure on this program in both 1994-95 and 1995-96. Funding of $60.8 million (including $18.8 million in unpaid Commonwealth funds carried forward from 1992-93) will be available for payment under the CHP in 1993-94, with $62 million in new funds allocated in 1994-95 and $69 million in 1995-96.

The Government is also committed to the continuing provision of assistance to people in housing crisis. Total Commonwealth funds available for expenditure on the Crisis Accommodation Program (CAP) in 1993-94 amount to $73.6 million, comprising $36.2 million in new funds, $7.1 million in unpaid Commonwealth funds carried over from 1992-93, and an additional $30.3 million in unspent CAP funds already held by the States. The total amount available in 1993-94 is some $20 million more than was spent in 1992-93.
Compared with this level of funds, the proposed cut to CAP funds of $3.5 million is modest—a reduction of less than 5 per cent of total funds for 1993-94.

The decision to make this adjustment to CAP funding in 1993-94 was taken in the light of a pattern of significant under expenditure in the program. At 30 June 1993, over $37 million in previous years' allocations remained unspent.

Program under expenditure has been partly attributable to an inability to plan projects on the basis of funds becoming available in subsequent years. This constraint has been removed, with States now able to anticipate Commonwealth funding up to 1995-96.

The Commonwealth has also included CAP in the new cash management arrangements for the CSHA which were introduced in 1992-93. Under these arrangements, Commonwealth funds will only be advanced to States as required—payments are made no more than a month in advance of estimated expenditure. Together with the ability to better plan outlays as a result of the forward commitment capability, this is expected to provide a significant incentive to improve program performance and reduce unspent funds.

As the capital funding arm of the Supported Accommodation Assistance Program (SAAP), CAP featured in the recent national evaluation of SAAP. The evaluation concluded that SAAP has fulfilled an essential role in funding the crisis and transitional accommodation needed by homeless people (113 dwellings with 480 beds were approved in 1992-93).

However, there is some criticism of the relative inflexibility with which funds have been applied: there has been an over emphasis on the design and construction of dwellings rather than purchase, and insufficient attention to leasing options. These matters will be addressed in the development of strategic directions for SAAP commissioned by Social Welfare Ministers, and in the CAP review commissioned by Housing Ministers.

In amending section 15 of the act by adding a new subsection 15(2A), the amendment to the bill sets out provision for the Commonwealth Minister to authorise the full level of untied grants to a particular State in 1994-95 even if the Minister cannot ensure that the State can meet the balance of its matching obligation from the value of home loans provided through its home purchase assistance programs in accordance with paragraph 13(2)(b) of the CSHA.

The addition of a new section 15A sets out provision for the Commonwealth Minister effectively to waive or reduce a State or Territory's obligation to match the balance of untied assistance, provided by the Commonwealth to a State for housing assistance from the value of home loans provided through home purchase assistance programs—this provision will apply only for 1993-94 and 1994-95.
These amendments will not, however, relieve an affected State of its grant matching obligations under the Agreement.
Commonwealth untied assistance provided under the CSHA to the States and Territories is used for a number of purposes, predominantly for building or purchase of public rental housing stock.

The CSHA requires States to match this untied assistance on a dollar-for-dollar basis, with at least half of the matching provided through State grants and the balance through the value of loans made under home purchase assistance schemes.

However, difficulties have recently arisen as a result of lower demand for home purchase assistance products and the relatively attractive terms of commercial products in the current economic climate. The affected States have also indicated that they are not able to provide additional grant funding to meet the 1993-94 matching obligation.

In the case of 1993-94, where it has become evident that some States will not undertake sufficient lending under their home purchase assistance programs to meet their obligations under the Agreement, the CSHA provides for the Commonwealth to recover financial assistance already provided.

In the case of 1994-95, where some States have indicated that they are unlikely to be able to meet their matching requirements, the Housing Assistance Act requires that the Minister not provide funds which will not be matched. This effectively means that the Commonwealth must reduce untied grants for public housing provision to a level that will be matched.

The Government considers that either to recover financial assistance already provided or to reduce funding to be provided would be undesirable. It would reduce funds for public housing and, in light of the current demand for such housing, would disadvantage those most in need of assistance. Also, it would be undesirable to pursue such action where States are genuinely unable to meet such requirements because of changed market conditions.

To force States to increase lending at this time solely to meet their matching requirements may result in loans being made to more and more marginal clients. This could impact adversely on the viability of the overall home lending program in the longer term as well as creating problems for clients should their circumstances change.

Any decision to waive or reduce the home purchase assistance matching requirement will only be taken after careful consideration of the circumstances leading to the need for such a course of action and will be determined on a case-by-case basis. Issues taken into account when making this decision will include the economic environment in the relevant grant year, the availability of alternative home lending finance products to low to moderate income earners, a State's lending effort and commitment in previous years and the nature of the programs being offered by an affected State.

It is not possible at this time to detail specifically the extent of any waiver or reduction of the home purchase assistance matching requirement. The financial information required for 1993-94 will not be available until the end of the financial year, and in the case of 1994-95 States are not required, under the Agreement, to provide details of their matching proposals until 31 March this year, and even this will be based on estimated levels of lending only. However, in 1993-94 it would appear that New South Wales will have a shortfall of the order of $130 million (their total obligation); Victoria's is difficult to estimate as it will depend on the take-up rate of its new shared home ownership program, which is likely to be introduced progressively from April; and Tasmania's shortfall is estimated at this time to be around $2 million. The Minister for Housing, Local Government and Human Services will be pursuing the issue of 1994-95 matching with the States.

Any determination will only be made after consultation with the relevant State Minister, and after the Federal Minister for Housing, Local Government and Human Services is satisfied that this course of action is the most appropriate. In the case of 1994-95 any action will only be taken after consideration by the Government. To ensure ongoing Parliamentary oversight these determinations will be tabled.

This remedy to current difficulties will not be open-ended. It is intended only as a short term response to ensure that those in need of public housing are not disadvantaged. Policy in the home purchase assistance area is being considered in consultation with the States and Territories, and in the context of the Government's consideration of the Industry Commission report on public housing and other housing policy issues.

In summary, the bill provides for variations in expenditure made available for various programs funded under the CSHA for the years 1993 to 1996 and its provisions reflect the level of housing activity which is expected to be achieved during this period. The bill also provides for the Minister to waive or reduce a State or Territory's obligation to match the balance of untied assistance from the value of home loans provided through home purchase assistance programs for 1993-94 and 1994-95 only.

The bill is consistent with improved cash management arrangements for the CSHA which have been negotiated successfully with the States by the Commonwealth Government. These arrangements provide for improved accountability for Commonwealth funds which are provided to the States under the CSHA.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Industry, Science, Technology, Transport, Communications and Infrastructure Committee

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That, noting that the Government is close to finalising a Nuclear Science and Technology Co-operation Agreement with Indonesia which will foreshadow the future sale of uranium to Indonesia; expressing concern that the Government, through the co-operation agreement, has given its endorsement to Indonesia's nuclear energy program; condemning the Government for the secrecy surrounding Australia's bilateral nuclear agreements; and noting that Indonesia plans to build nuclear reactors in a region of high seismic activity and that the degree of that activity exceeds the maximum recommended by its own nuclear agency as acceptable, the following matter be referred to the Standing Committee on Industry, Science, Technology, Transport, Communications and Infrastructure:

SPEECH.PARA: The details and arrangements which are covered under any nuclear co-operation agreement, including the draft Indonesian agreement, in particular, the degree to which such arrangements are considered to be in the `national interest' and whether or not they obligate Australia to operate a nuclear reactor.

This motion concerns the plan by Indonesia to build 12 600-megawatt nuclear power stations on Java and seeks to refer this matter to the Standing Committee on Industry, Science, Technology, Transport, Communications and Infrastructure. Despite the fact that this motion has been on the Notice Paper for some time, I have to tell the Senate and those listening outside that I have failed to convince either the government or the opposition that this is an appropriate technical matter to be dealt with by that committee. I expect that this motion will be voted down without any debate, but I wish to make a few remarks to indicate the importance the Australian Democrats attach to this particular matter.

PARA.TAB: We have felt for quite a long time that nuclear power is inherently dangerous—that it is a technology fraught with a number of very particular and very idiosyncratic dangers which spread far beyond the borders of the country which may choose to use nuclear power. Indeed, it was back in the late 1960s or early 1970s that Alvin Weinberg, a nuclear scientist in the US and a strong nuclear advocate, spoke of the need to establish what he called a nuclear priesthood—a priestly class of people whose job in perpetuity, for generation after generation, would be the care of nuclear power. As the older members of this chamber will recall, he was the one who invented the term `Faustian bargain', the bargain by which, in return for nuclear power and nuclear electricity, we would have to set up this nuclear priesthood—these people who would, by profession and for the whole of their lives, look to the security of nuclear power.

Some nations have entered into that Faustian bargain and some nations, such as Russia, with its Chernobyl reactor, have come unstuck and have had to pay an awful price for having entered into that bargain. Another example is India, and I mention it for a particular reason. India is a developing nation, rather like Indonesia, where the technology has not been carefully looked after. Large parts of India around nuclear installations have become extensively polluted with radioactive contamination.

There are risks directly associated with the technology—the inability to control the spread of radioactive material either from the mining of uranium, its enrichment, the handling of the fuels, from the nuclear power stations themselves, from the very processing facilities, the very long-term storage which is necessary, and also from the decommissioning of nuclear power stations. But there is also a military connection.

With Indonesia, that is a very interesting connection. Quite recently, no less an organisation than the United States Pentagon drew attention to the very close links between civil nuclear programs and the acquisition of nuclear materials and technology which would allow nations clandestinely, despite non-proliferation treaties and bilateral treaties, to acquire the facilities to make nuclear weapons. Honourable senators may have forgotten the fact that some years ago, when Indonesia first went down this nuclear road, it sought to buy Candu reactors—Canadian deuterium uranium reactors—which use heavy water as a moderator and unenriched uranium. They have the advantage of making twice as much plutonium as the American light water reactors and can be unloaded while on-line. In other words, the fuel can be progressively taken out without shutting down the reactor, while the unloading escapes detection by international agents from the International Atomic Energy Agency.

Honourable senators would also be aware that North Korea at this very time is failing to allow the international inspection which would allow us to be certain that it is not using its civil nuclear reactors as a means of acquiring nuclear weapons and possibly threatening that part of the world. Honourable senators will probably also recall the problems we had with Iraq—the building of the French reactor in Baghdad—and the way in which the Israelis went in some years ago with a pre-emptive strike, recognising the enormous risks to Israel presented by the Iraqis acquiring nuclear weapons through the facility of a civil nuclear reactor.

Honourable senators may not be as aware that, before the overthrow of the Shah of Iran, Germany was about to build a number of nuclear reactors in Iran and also provide the reprocessing facilities which would have given Iran access to plutonium and materials to make nuclear weapons. Of course, the overthrow of the Shah and the general turmoil in that part of the world led to the abandonment of that program and those nuclear reactors were not built. But one could well imagine the horrific circumstance that might have obtained in the Middle East had Iran and Iraq both had access to nuclear weapons—and that is really saying something, given the fires in the oil wells and so on. I have no doubt that they would have used them and that those weapons would have been acquired through legitimate civil nuclear programs.

Returning to the first concern—the dangers from the reactors themselves—as I said, Indonesia plans to build 12 600-megawatt reactors on Java, in the middle of one of the most seismically active areas in the world. Indeed, on the weekend I read in a copy of Science that some 70,000 years ago probably one of the world's worst volcanic eruptions occurred quite close by on Sumatra which resulted in a mini ice age, the extinction of many species, a spreading of the ice sheet across much of North America and Europe. For the humans of that time it must have been incredibly distressing with the great loss of life. Just in the last century and a half, one has seen a number of major earthquakes and volcanic eruptions in the Indonesian archipelago, extending all the way from Sumatra through to Papua New Guinea.

The Indonesian nuclear authorities themselves have said they should not build nuclear power stations in areas where the expectation of an earthquake would exceed 6.7 on the Richter scale, and yet Java is expected to have earthquakes of eight on the Richter scale. I remind senators that that scale is a logarithmic scale and when we go from Richter seven to Richter eight there is a ten-fold increase in the amount of energy and the damage which can result from those earthquakes.

The Democrats believe very considerable risks are associated with the plans by Indonesia to build these nuclear power stations in that region. Given the prevailing winds, should the nuclear power stations rupture and release the sort of radioactivity that occurred from the Chernobyl reactor—although they are not going to be of that type; their rupture would occur through an earthquake, not because of some fault in the reactor—the likelihood of radioactive contamination across the northern parts of Australia and also Papua New Guinea is very high indeed, with enormous risks to human life and the environment generally.

The reasons Indonesia is choosing to go down this road are not clear at all. There is no doubt that nuclear power stations are expensive, that nuclear power will not provide for the needs of most of Indonesia's people, given the fact that Indonesia is scattered over some 2,000 islands. Moreover, it has available other sources of energy which it could use which would be, in fact, cheaper. Indonesia, as the parliamentary committee found, has some 2.2 per cent of the world's known gas reserves, and on a per capita basis this is approximately the average allocation. Eighty five per cent of that is being exported to Japan. Those who would argue using gas would add to greenhouse emissions are ignoring the fact that gas is being exploited now, anyway, and causing greenhouse gas emissions. It would simply be a matter of using that for Indonesia's indigenous supply of electricity.

There is also a very considerable availability of geothermal energy, some 16 gigowatts. Sixteen thousand megawatts of power could be derived from geothermal sources. Some 75 gigowatts—10 times the amount which could be derived from nuclear sources—could be derived from hydro-electric installations. There is considerable concern that such large installations would cause severe disruption in many areas and would be resisted by many people. Small hydro-electric schemes are precisely the sorts of things likely to give electricity to people at the village level and substantially improve their life, whereas large central nuclear power stations on Java are not likely to do so. There is also considerable possibility for solar hot water for cooking purposes which could again be used at the village level and in which Australia could play a very significant part in helping the Indonesian people.

So, it is with great regret that I have to report all these technical questions in relation to seismicity in Java and to the risks associated with nuclear damage from these proposed 12 nuclear power stations, the risks to northern Australia and our neighbours in Papua New Guinea, the technical issues of the links between civil and military nuclear programs, so evident in other countries, will not be taken up by the Senate Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology. It is also a great pity with respect to Australia's involvement that it seems as though we are being led down the road towards closer association and cooperation with this Indonesian program without either the Australian people or the parliament being told exactly what it is we are entering into.

Over some years I have raised with the foreign minister, Senator Evans, the question of what sorts of arrangements have been entered into with Indonesia. At each stage I have been put off with quite bland assertions that very little has been agreed to. Yet, when I ask a question approximately a year later, I find a great deal has been negotiated and the parliament has not been told. It would be very appropriate for us to have this inquiry, but I repeat that neither the government nor the opposition is prepared to agree to this. Despite having put this motion off for some time in the hope that the government and opposition might have changed their minds, it is with great regret, nonetheless, that they are not prepared to look at this issue. I fully expect that the motion will be voted down.
Question resolved in the negative.

DEBATE.TITLE: PRIME MINISTER AND CABINET (MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS) BILL 1993

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 16 December 1993, on motion by Senator Faulkner:
That this bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —The coalition supports this legislation. It is obvious from the title it is a miscellaneous provision bill and, therefore, is dealing with changes to a number of pieces of legislation. The changes vary in consequence. Some are quite important, others are of much less consequence.

PARA.TAB: I mention some of the areas that have been the subject of considerable public debate and explain briefly the coalition's position and why we in fact have decided to support the amendments. Some of the most important changes are to the archives and freedom of information acts dealing with the question of cabinet notebooks.

It has been the subject of considerable public debate for some time as to whether or not it is appropriate for cabinet notebooks to be made public, and in what circumstances they should be made public; in other words, whether publication would prejudice confidentiality of cabinet conduct.

It was of such concern to the government a few years ago that there was discussion between the parties about what the attitude would be to the government introducing further restrictive legislation. The real concern was the interpretation of the provisions under the Freedom of Information Act. There was some doubt as to how those provisions might be interpreted. It was thought by some that there would be a somewhat liberal interpretation which would oblige a previously unprecedented disclosure of this area of confidential cabinet records. The case of the Commonwealth and the Northern Land Council reported in 1993 put to rest much of the concern previously expressed.

In its decision of April of that year, the High Court held that documents recording the deliberations of cabinet fall within a class in respect of which strong considerations of public policy mitigate against disclosure. The court held that only in quite exceptional circumstances, where there was a significant likelihood that the public interest in due administration of justice outweighed the public interest in confidentiality of cabinet documents, would their production be ordered in court. We support that decision. It seems to us that this is a matter best left to the courts. We are comforted by the fact that, in the future, courts following that precedent will properly understand the importance of the principle of confidentiality and would need to find that a circumstance exists where due administration of justice outweighs public interest in confidentiality before an order for disclosure is made.

On the other hand, there is obviously an important function in releasing documents for historical purposes. The government has decided in this instance to amend the Archives Act 1993 so that cabinet notebooks would be accessible after a period of 50 years rather than the more standard period of 30 years. That seems to us to be sensible. Having also made that change by this legislation, the Freedom of Information Act is then amended to make clear that cabinet documents are excluded from the operation of the act. With this package, the large administrative costs of receiving and processing an application under the Freedom of Information Act will not be incurred; the court will make the determination as to whether the circumstances justify release; and the documents will be open to public scrutiny for historical purposes after a period of 50 years. On balance, that is a reasonable compromise and we are prepared to support it.

For the same reason that cabinet notebooks should be kept as a record of cabinet deliberations—to be referred to by future cabinets when wanting to clarify issues in relation to decision-making processes of cabinet—it is important to stress that other documents should also be kept. It was most disturbing to the coalition to note reports that out-going ministers of the Victorian state Labor government had shredded state cabinet documents. We trust that would not occur at a federal level under the administration of this government. We would appreciate assurances as to the safekeeping by the Commonwealth government of all its formal cabinet records.

The Australian Science and Technology Council Act 1978 is amended. This seems to be principally an administrative change and I do not dwell on it. However, there are important amendments to the Merit Protection (Australian Government Employees) Act 1984 that I want to mention. The first amendment is to clarify the fact that the Merit Protection and Review Agency has jurisdiction over Commonwealth employees employed by a statutory authority under an industrial award. I am advised that this was always understood to be the intention, but that doubt arose. This amendment is designed to overcome that uncertainty.

This legislation would apply retrospectively, and we always look at anything with a retrospective consequence with great care. We have been convinced that the amendment has the effect of preserving the status of matters dealt with by the agency over the last 10 years and therefore should be allowed. The individual awards would have to allow for reference to the Merit Protection and Review Agency before this provision would apply. If they do, we have no problems in that regard and support the amendment which, we were told, is simply to implement what was always understood to be the case.

The second amendment complements a proposed amendment to the Ombudsman Act 1976 to allow for transfer of complaints between the two agencies, depending on which agency could more appropriately deal with the complaint. That would appear to be a sensible rationalisation of functions, and it also has our support. The act has a number of changes made to it by virtue of this bill. They arise out of consideration of the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration, entitled Review of the Office of the Commonwealth Ombudsman, released in December 1991. The government responded in December 1992, and we finally have this legislation.

One amendment facilitates the transfer of complaints between the Australian Broadcasting Authority and the ombudsman. This arose from the recommendation of the Senate committee that the ombudsman should have jurisdiction to deal with complaints from persons and organisations claiming to have been misrepresented on ABC programs. In the event of a jurisdictional dispute continuing, the government would consider other legislative options. As I understand it, the advice of the committee was rejected in that regard. The government considered that the ABA provides an adequate forum for persons claiming to have been misrepresented on ABC and SBS programs. The ombudsman, however, retains jurisdiction over action relating to matters of administration, including those arising in the preparation and broadcast of programs. If I have understood the measure correctly, it is reasonable, and we support it.

The Senate committee also recommended that the jurisdiction of the Merit Protection and Review Agency to investigate employment related grievances be transferred to the ombudsman. The government decided not to implement this recommendation because removal of such an important function from the MPRA could jeopardise its status as a major element in Public Service management and industrial relations. Again, the government decided instead to facilitate the transfer of complaints between the two. We think that that is a reasonable position and should be supported.

Thirdly, the Senate committee recommended that the government consider assigning the role of the telecommunications industry ombudsman to the Commonwealth ombudsman and that future decisions to establish specialist ombudsmen institutions be made having regard to whether the Commonwealth ombudsman could perform the particular function. The government decided that the telecommunications industry ombudsman scheme should reflect the commercial nature of the industry and cater for the commercial manner in which the participants wish to deal with customer complaints and that therefore it was not appropriate to extend the Commonwealth ombudsman's jurisdiction to the private sector participants in the industry. We are prepared to support that approach.

I also wanted to mention some of the changes to the Public Service Act 1922 and the Superannuation Act 1976 that this bill would effect. Firstly, the bill amends the Public Service Act to allow for departments to apply an order of merit principle when filling positions which were filled on the advice of a joint selection committee and become vacant within six months of the original appointment. Currently, if the original position becomes vacant or an identical position in the same department becomes vacant, the department would have to go through the normal recruitment procedure to fill the position.

Pursuant to these amendments, the next applicant in order of merit can be offered the position if it becomes vacant within six months of the original position being offered. That seems to be a sensible saving of resources and we support it. Secondly, the bill contains amendments relating to disciplinary measures to bring the range of penalties currently available for unattached officers into line with those available for attached officers. Whilst I will not detail them, we think that that is sensible also and should be supported.

It seems to us that the principal amendments in relation to the Public Service are those which relate to fixed term appointments for secretaries of departments. The government is proposing to allow all persons appointed to the position of departmental secretary the option of accepting a fixed term contract with higher remuneration in exchange for their long-term tenure in the Public Service. Existing departmental secretaries and appointments from inside the Public Service to the position will be given the option of a fixed term contract of up to five years and an increase in salary of 20 per cent on the condition that they resign from the Australian Public Service, effectively forgoing their residual rights to tenure in the service.

The option will be extended to both existing departmental secretaries and future appointments from inside and outside the Public Service. The option will also be available to six statutory officers: the Auditor-General; the Public Service Commissioner; the Commissioner of Taxation; the Australian Statistician; the head of ATSIC; and the Comptroller-General of Customs. However, in relation to these statutory appointments no legislative change is necessary.

The Remuneration Tribunal has indicated in principle agreement to the additional remuneration of 20 per cent above the current salary of departmental secretaries. Other terms and conditions of appointment will not be affected and there is no limitation on the number of successive contracts that might be entered into if both parties agree.

Currently, the act allows only for people appointed to the position of departmental secretary from outside the Public Service to be employed on a fixed term contract. Of course, this means that the appointment does not give them tenure in the Public Service beyond the terms of the contract. The act stipulates that the contract can be no longer than five years and cannot be extended to someone beyond the age of 65. In effect, this change gives the option of buying out tenure with terms and conditions agreed between the parties. We think that it is a sensible reform that will give greater flexibility at the top of the Public Service.

Mr Acting Deputy President, as you would be aware some of the states are now negotiating packages for very senior officers in the Public Service at much higher rates of remuneration. It is necessary for the Commonwealth to be competitive. It is also necessary for the Commonwealth to have the flexibility to attract the best, whether from within or without the Public Service. We therefore accept this change. Although some might see it as some sort of hidden pay rise, we recognise that something is being given up to get it and that is what enterprise bargaining is supposed to be all about.

There are other changes to the Royal Commissions Act and the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation Act but I do not need to refer to them specifically now. In summary, we support the legislation. We do, however, raise that concern that came out of the public reports, that the Victorian state Labor government may have shredded state cabinet documents. We look forward to some reassurance from the minister at the table, Senator Sherry, the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, or from the representative of the minister that that would not occur at this level of government.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats will not be opposing the Prime Minister and Cabinet (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bill but we have three concerns that we want to place on the record. The first relates to public access to cabinet notebooks. As Senator Hill said, under this bill cabinet notebooks will no longer be excluded from the provisions of the Archives Act. The public will now have access to those notebooks for the first time. However, the bill protects those notebooks for a 50-year period, which is 20 years longer than for other confidential or protected documents under FOI legislation.

PARA.TAB: While we accept the argument that, because of their particularly sensitive nature, cabinet notebooks probably warrant a greater degree of protection than that accorded other cabinet documents, we have a few reservations about whether an extra 20 years is required. We are also mindful of the fact that any exemptions to the Freedom of Information Act only serve to undermine the object of the act, which is `to extend as far as possible the right of the Australian community to access to information in the possession of the government of the Commonwealth'.

I accept that cabinet and executive council documents require some additional protection and that, as the High Court decided last year, there are strong public policy considerations which weigh against the production of cabinet notebooks. However, balanced against that is the need to be sending a very strong message to the Australian community that our public institutions are not afraid of and in fact welcome close public scrutiny.

At a time when the public is demanding, and rightly so, much greater accountability from government and a much higher standard of openness from its elected representatives, it is disappointing to find governments failing to respond to these concerns with the sort of integrity and honesty that the public has a right to expect from them. We have heard the word `accountability' bandied around a lot in this place and in the media recently. I would not wish to see that word become devalued by over-use but the public has a right to expect its elected representatives to be accountable for their actions. As I said, although I would have preferred to see cabinet notebooks become available after 30 years rather than 50, I accept that the provisions of this bill represent a step forward in the cause of public accountability.

The second area I want to note is the change to the Commonwealth Ombudsman's powers. As we have heard, the bill expands the ombudsman's investigatory powers to include the administrative actions of the High Court, the Federal Court, the Family Court, the Administrative Appeals Tribunal registries, the Commonwealth parliamentary departments and Commonwealth controlled companies; a discretion to decline to investigate the commercial activities of Commonwealth agencies; and the capacity to transfer complaints to the Australian Broadcasting Authority, the Merit Protection and Review Agency or industry ombudsman. These changes came out of the review of the Office of the Ombudsman carried out by the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration.

It is pleasing to see a government respond to the changes recommended by a Senate committee. We welcome these changes, but we urge the minister to ensure that the Commonwealth Ombudsman actually has the financial resources to meet these additional obligations. We all know how the best efforts can be stymied through a lack of resources. The Auditor-General could well be a case in point.

The third area involves changes to the Public Service Act and the Superannuation Act. The bill includes amendments which will enable the government to give effect to its decision to allow Australian Public Service departmental secretaries and a number of equal level statutory office holders to relinquish their continuing tenure in the Public Service in return for a reasonable loading on their salaries. That loading will be set by the Remuneration Tribunal. I understand that the government has recommended to the tribunal that that loading be set at 20 per cent. Senator Hill said that the Remuneration Tribunal had accepted that. Perhaps the parliamentary secretary could comment on that.

This seems to be a somewhat illusory trade-off because in many ways, I think it is true, departmental secretaries do not have a great deal of security. I am sure that many secretaries will not be overly concerned about giving up their pretty precarious tenure in exchange for a healthy pay rise. The Democrats will not be opposing these measures, but we do want to place on the parliamentary record our concern about the trend towards the increasing politicisation of the most senior levels of the Public Service. I put the government on notice that we will be watching the development of this trade-off measure very closely to ensure that it does not exacerbate or accelerate that trend.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to respond to one matter raised by Senator Hill and a couple of matters raised by Senator Kernot. Senator Hill raised the matter of the alleged destruction of cabinet documents on the cessation of office by ministers in the previous Labor government in Victoria.

PARA.TAB: Cabinet documents—at least at the federal level—are kept in accordance with the rules and procedures under the Archives Act, and referred to in the cabinet handbook. Under the Archives Act cabinet documents are the property of the Commonwealth and not individual ministers. So ministers are requested to either return copies of cabinet documents to the Cabinet Office—and they are obviously kept within the provisions of the Archives Act—or to destroy them on leaving office.

When we talk about `destroying', it is only in the sense that we do not need to keep 50 copies of the same document. The original documents have already been kept. There is no question of cabinet records being destroyed by this government in the sense referred to by Senator Hill, should we leave office. Copies of cabinet documents are available under the Archives Act after the 30 years that are provided, and there are no relevant exceptions.

Three issues were touched on by Senator Kernot. The first was the issue of the notebooks, and whether or not the 20-year differential was too great a degree of protection vis-a-vis cabinet documents, which have 30 years protection. I am advised that the bill exempts notebooks totally from the Freedom of Information Act, but brings them within the Archives Act.
The notebooks have never been available at all under freedom of information. Senator Kernot conceded that this is an improvement, but she was not sure whether it went far enough.

TALK.START.PARA: —We just want to be alive to read them!

—If I ever get to that exalted position I am not sure I would want to be sitting in bed at night reading cabinet notebooks 50 years hence, or even 30 years hence! But the government takes the view that it would be unreasonable for elderly former ministers to be dragged into controversy long after leaving public life. So if I ever enjoy that distinguished position—distinguished, but I hope not extinguished—50 years after being a minister—
—Does that mean we can expect them to retire earlier?
—I must say that I think there is a general trend towards younger retirements.
—We are working on your forced retirement!

—I thank Senator O'Chee for his particular attention! I think there is a general trend towards younger people in politics. The 50 years is an assessment—I do not think anyone has worked out the average life expectancy of politicians after leaving the cabinet—but I do not think too many live beyond 50 years after leaving the cabinet.

PARA.TAB: The second matter that Senator Kernot raised was the financial resources that are given to the Office of the Ombudsman. I understand that, as a result of the Senate inquiry into the ombudsman's office, which has been referred to in this debate, the government considered the financial position and provided an additional injection of funds, the up-dating of the computer system and extra staffing resources. The amount was slightly less than $1 million—I cannot give the exact figure. So that was in direct response to the matters raised in that Senate report. We can always argue about whether resources are sufficient or not, but certainly additional resources were made available.

The third point that Senator Kernot touched on was the additional payment of 20 per cent in respect of secretaries who voluntarily—I think that should be stressed; it is in the second reading speech and the notes and advisory documents—relinquish their permanency. That has been advised by the Remuneration Tribunal. It is the organisation that is best placed to make these decisions. I understand it is not formalised yet, but certainly the informal indication is that that is the approximate figure that should be looked at in terms of the compensation to those people, should they relinquish their permanency.
Those were the matters that were raised, and those are the concluding comments I wish to make.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

DEBATE.TITLE: SOCIAL SECURITY (HOME CHILD CARE AND PARTNER ALLOWANCES) LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1993

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the House of Representatives be requested to make the following amendments:
Clause 3, pages 11 and 12, proposed section 926, line 30 (page 11) to line 10 (page12), omit the section, substitute the following section:

"926. For the purposes of this Division, "`ordinary income'" means income of a person that would be separate net income of the person for the purposes of section 159J of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 as in force on 30 June 1994.".
Clause 3, page 13, after proposed Division 5, insert the following Division:

PARA.EMPHASIS: Preservation of home child care allowance where rebates would be available

SPEECH.PARA: (a)a home child care allowance is not payable to a person for a dependent child during a period but would be so payable apart from sections 902, 903, 904, 905, 907 and 918 and paragraphs 906(c) and (d); and

(b)under subsection 159J(1B) of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 as in force on 30 June 1994, the person or the person's spouse would be entitled to a rebate at a higher rate in respect of the child for the year of income in which that period occurred;
a home child care allowance is payable to the person for the child during that period.".

The first amendment, which is to omit proposed section 926 and substitute another section, is designed to overcome what I believe is a problem with this legislation. It is important for the committee to understand the import of these amendments I have just moved, to ensure that no family currently receiving the DSR through the taxation system is worse off under this particular measure. In other words, it is really to keep the government honest.

PARA.TAB: The Prime Minister (Mr Keating) announced that there would be a home child-care allowance. He said that this would apply to all the families currently receiving the DSR. That was the message received by the community at large prior to the last election. This legislation attempts to take away the DSR from families with at least one child and sometimes more children and which were previously receiving the maximum DSR. Now some of those families are going to have that taken away from them completely or the amount will be reduced, for some unknown reason, to the equivalent of the DSR for a family with no children. Families with children will now be in the situation where their DSR equivalent will be at the rate of a family with no children. There is no rhyme or reason in that.

In addition, the interpretation of ordinary income under this proposal will take money away from people by stealth. The definition of ordinary income for the purposes of the dependent spouse rebate income test is different from the one proposed here. The old concept in the tax law of separate net income meant that income, according to ordinary concepts, did not include occasional windfalls or gifts.

Under this legislation, the new social security definition for ordinary income includes a wider range of potential receipts. People who previously would have qualified for the DSR will now be denied part or all of it as it is being cashed up into the home child-care and partner allowance. Is that fair? I do not believe it is fair. If the government were doing this, it really should have been quite open with people and told them that prior to the election, but it did not.

No families that I know of believed that they would lose out as a result of the government's change in definition. Indeed, the social security definition can include deemed income, which is not income at all. My amendment is designed to restore the status quo to avoid detriment to any family. I believe that that was the Prime Minister's intention prior to the last election. I have not heard anything since to alter that belief.

The second amendment is fairly clear. The home child-care allowance will not be available where a child is a student over 16 or outside Australia. The existing dependent spouse rebate is available in all these cases. Again, the principle of this measure is simply to maintain the status quo for families, not to use this as a device to take away from families money which they are already getting.

I will give honourable senators an example. If a family has a student child on Austudy, it gets the DSR of $14.25. Under this proposal, the cashed up amount is the equivalent of the DSR for a childless couple. Why should those people lose $237 by being cut out from the HCCA and put onto the spouse rebate for a childless couple? I ask the committee: does a child cost $237 less once the child becomes a student? What is the difference before and after? I will give another example. At the moment couples with student children up to the age of 25 years get a DSR of $14.25. Under this bill, families will be denied HCCA once the last child is over 16 and leaves school or turns 18.

I appeal to the Labor members to understand this. Some years ago the government abolished the dole for 16-year-olds on the basis that their parents, not the taxpayer, should look after them. But now, under this measure, it says that the child does not exist at all for the purposes of the cashed up DSR, which will be the new home child-care allowance. If parents kick a child out because they are too broke to pay the bills, the government will fork out the young homeless child allowance. Why not recognise in this measure the fact that that child is dependent upon the family? The government has made him or her dependent on the family by cutting out the dole at 16.

I want to give honourable senators another example of a situation where families will be worse off under this measure than they were under the DSR, and it applies to Australians who are posted overseas for a period while the remaining legal residents are paying Australian taxes. Persons who come to mind are diplomats, soldiers and missionaries; this was discussed by most honourable senators contributing to this debate in the second reading stage. At the moment families in this category get the higher level of DSR of $14.25 where there are children. They too will be ripped off by $237.

The question is why? Why can a family not go overseas for more than 13 weeks? Many families have to go. Why can a family not leave a child overseas for a few months with a relative to complete the year's schooling whilst the rest of the family completes a posting and returns to Australia? That regularly happens in the diplomatic service. I believe that these questions are legitimate and deserve responses. What legitimate reason can there be for stripping families in these sorts of situations of $237?

I finally make the point to the committee that I am not asking for anything more for families than they already get. I am saying we should not disadvantage them. In this International Year of the Family we should not take away from families what they are already entitled to. That is what the government is doing with this legislation.

My amendments are in the form of a request to the House of Representatives. I do not want anyone here to run away with the idea that I am suggesting that my amendments will mean an additional burden on the taxpayer or the government purse. I am trying to make sure that people will be able to maintain what they are entitled to now—with, of course, the generous amount of $2.60 per week, which is the net increase being proposed by the government. In all fairness, my amendments should be supported and deserve support.

TALK.START.PARA: —The amendments that Senator Harradine has circulated are, in fact, in the spirit of the amendment calling on the government to address this issue that I moved in my speech during the second reading debate. As Senator Harradine pointed out, Mr Keating said at the last election that families would be given a home child-care allowance. There was no indication that certain families would be excluded—families who were eligible for the dependent spouse rebate but who, because of differences between the Social Security Act and the taxation act, would be excluded. We called on the government to make those amendments.

PARA.TAB: Senator Lees claimed that I said I did not have time to make amendments. As I said in my personal explanation, that was not the case; I did not say that at all. Senator Lees said that because the Social Security (Home Child Care and Partner Allowances) Legislation Amendment Bill had to be passed that day—I do not understand why that had to be the case—the Australian Democrats would not support my amendment.

My amendment called on the government to ensure that people with children who are currently eligible for the dependent spouse rebate are not prevented from transferring to the home child-care allowance. It also called on the government to ensure that there should not be a difference in eligibility depending on residency requirements, age, whether the child is a prescribed student, or the definition of income. The amendments that Senator Harradine has brought forward address those issues.

The Minister for Family Services (Senator Crowley) might stand up—I do not know whether she is going to; I do not have a crystal ball—and pick holes in these amendments. But if she does, I will say to her, `You had your chance, minister, when I moved an amendment during the second reading debate to move your own amendments to address the concerns that are being expressed by Senator Harradine and by the coalition. She had the opportunity to bring these amendments before us and she did not do so.

It was confirmed in a letter from George Gear to Senator Lees that the old disability spouse rebate for dependent spouses with children will be abolished altogether. This means that families who are prevented from transferring to the home child-care allowance, due, as I said, to residency requirements, age, or income definitions, or the fact that they are prescribed students, will not even be able to claim the dependent spouse rebate at the dependent spouse with children rate. They will be able to receive the dependent spouse rebate only at the lower rate for dependent spouses without children. This means that such families will be $237 worse off than they are now. They will be $372 worse off than families with dependent spouses and children receiving the home child-care allowance. Why are these families worse off? As I said, they are worse off because they do not fulfil the residency requirements, because of the age of the student, because families have prescribed students, or because there are differences in the definition of income.

I do not believe that many of those families who heard the pea and thimble promise by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) that a person at home was going to get $30 ever understood that the dependent spouse rebate was going to be taken away and a small increase of $2.60 added to it to form the home child-care allowance. As I said before in the second reading debate, it really was a sleight of hand on the part the Prime Minister. But it seems to me that because of this sleight of hand, a number of families have missed out. Senator Harradine has tried to address that issue.

I would like the minister to confirm this: it is my understanding that public servants on postings would not be disadvantaged. Senator Harradine mentioned diplomats and others. I would like that clarified. But I would like the minister to clarify whether people such as missionaries, aid workers, and families of academics who are on study leave, who fulfil all the other requirements would be disadvantaged because they are away from Australia for more than 13 weeks. I would like to hear the minister's response to how the government can justify that these families are going to miss out. I would also like her to explain why Mr Keating did not make it clear to these families before the last election that they were going to miss out on this home child-care allowance.
