—In answer to Senator Panizza's first question, not much effort was put into running two systems at the same time. The idea of some people getting their dependent spouse rebate through the tax system and some getting it cashed out through the home child-care allowance would be an administrative nightmare.
—But the ones without children will still get it.

—Yes, they do, and they are a consistent block. But Senator Panizza is suggesting that some people could get their DSR on behalf of children through the husband's pay packet if the woman signed a piece of paper saying she was perfectly happy with that arrangement. I have to say it is a challenge to contemplate that. I would like to see Senator Panizza design the form. On all the evidence that I have had and which has come to government, there are women who are going to be very happy about that payment being paid directly to them.
—There is no argument about the definition of `couple'.

—I know that. I do not think many families are going to be unhappy if, under this new arrangement, the payment goes directly to the woman at home. I heard Senator Patterson raise the point that Senator Panizza has also raised about tax file numbers and that people, maybe for the first time in their lives, have to get a tax file number. It would be interesting to contemplate how many spouses will have to get one, particularly considering that many spouses are becoming dependent and previously were not. I suspect that many of those spouses have been in the work force and therefore already have a tax file number.

PARA.TAB: It is very difficult to work out how many spouses would need to apply for a tax file number. To be clear about this, the number of women who would need to apply for one to be eligible for the home child-care allowance is an ever decreasing and very small number. The definition of `couple' is contained in section 4 of the Social Security Act. That definition was fairly extensively canvassed previously. This procedure is consistent with that definition.

TALK.START.PARA: —Could Senator Crowley rule out a lesbian couple and homosexual couple for the purposes of this bill?
—The definition of a couple under social security legislation uses the words `a couple of people of the opposite sex'.

—I indicate the support of the Greens for Senator Harradine's amendments. There are two reasons for this support. The first reason is the understanding that this legislation should not disadvantage families previously in receipt of the maximum DSR. Senator Harradine said very succinctly that these amendments are in support of the status quo and an avoidance of detriment. Under this legislation, a family with a student on Austudy will lose between $230 and $300 a year and a family receiving the overseas allowance could lose $380 a year.

PARA.TAB: The second reason that we are supporting these amendments is that, while I accept the argument of the Minister for Family Services (Senator Crowley) that huge numbers of families will benefit from the change and we do feel that the move from the taxation system to the social security system has some advantages, there are also disadvantages. While the government is taking this payment from the tax rebate position to a benefit position—we acknowledge that is a considerable conceptual leap—it does increase involuntary inclusion on Department of Social Security lists. As Senator Panizza raised earlier, there is a question of whether this should be voluntary and be available to those who want to apply for the benefit, rather than automatically including them.

The government advice, which we do not accept—it argued not to support these amendments—is that this benefit is not available to sole parents with children overseas. It is only through these amendments to the home child-care allowance that the overseas benefit would extend beyond the 13-week period. This does not, in our opinion, justify not allowing it and disadvantaging those who currently enjoy that right through the previous DSR arrangement.

We believe that we should not argue to remove this possible benefit but instead argue to make it available to sole parents as well. So the principle is that children's allowances in these circumstances should be determined by their situation and not according to whether they have two parents or one. In conclusion, on the principle that families should not be worse off under this legislation than they were under the former DSR conditions, we will be supporting Senator Harradine's amendments.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am fascinated that Senator Chamarette should begin her remarks by citing Senator Harradine's `preservation of the status quo' because, if we were to preserve the status quo, 55,000 families would stand not to benefit. Preservation of the status quo is a very good definition of no change at all. Senator Harradine actually argues for preservation of the status quo, and Senator Chamarette so ably presented it to this chamber as a definition or a justification for supporting his amendments.

PARA.TAB: The preservation of the status quo would have been the very thing that allowed us not to move from the tax system to the social security system; would have allowed 55,000 families not to be advantaged; would have allowed the current inequities, I suppose, under the tax system of that payment actually going into a household payment; and would have allowed it not very often or not ever to be seen by the carer.

Here is a piece of legislation which, as Senator Chamarette said, offers conceptual change. That is exactly what this legislation does. I have said on a number of occasions that this is a watershed piece of legislation. It is something that many groups in the community, particularly women, have fought for for years because the status quo was not giving them access to money on behalf of themselves or their children. It sometimes went into the family pot, and many families of course happily adjusted. But we also know of very many families where it was very unhappily not accessible to that spouse at home, usually the wife. Preserving the status quo would not have assisted all those families; it would have perpetuated families where children and wives had to suffer because the payment was not going to them.

The price we pay for making this conceptual change is that very small numbers of people in a couple of categories will possibly not have access to the same advantage that they had before. That is the price that Senator Chamarette is asking me to forgo to preserve the status quo. I find that argument totally unpersuasive because, if we had not made this change, if we had not recognised the advantage to the parent at home—usually the mother—of cashing out this payment, we would have a less targeted payment. We would also not have the opportunity to recognise the important work the spouse at home is doing in caring for children, and we would not have the opportunity to make sure that a continuing, albeit modest, income continues to be paid to those spouses when they are out of the work force. The benefits of moving to the home child-care allowance and away from the tax system and its dependent spouse rebate are very persuasive, very overwhelming and are not the status quo.

I think a lot of us would have considerable sympathy for avoidance of detriment, but what we are seeking here is a balance. We are saying that the detriment is modest, it involves small numbers; and the benefits are huge. So, on balance, the definitions and the consistency that occur in moving this allowance away from the tax office and into the social security system are more than defensible; they are very justifiable. I think they deserve our support.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think I deserve a right of reply to the comments made by the Minister for Family Services (Senator Crowley). The minister took my statement out of context. I made it patently obvious that I understood the conceptual leap and that I saw that as progressing in a positive direction. What the minister is actually now arguing for in relation to this conceptual leap is that, for the benefits to be obtained, some people will have to be disadvantaged.

PARA.TAB: I put it to the minister that it is the government's responsibility, if it is going to make progressive changes, to ensure that the cost of those changes is not laid at the feet of people who had no idea that their circumstances would be altered in any way to their detriment by this legislation. I believe my argument still stands and my citing of Senator Harradine's comments, which has been taken out of context, should not be held against the overall principle which the minister is arguing, that some people will be disadvantaged and it does not matter because so many others will gain from this change.

I believe that the onus is on the government to make the changes and I commend it for making those that go in a positive direction. But two aspects are missing: firstly, it is to the detriment of some people, and that should be addressed; secondly, it involves some coercion and compulsory listing of changes from the taxation system to the social security system which may not be to everybody's approval. That option should be available to make it a voluntary rather than a compulsory change.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I pick up the last point Senator Chamarette raised; Senator Panizza, who, unfortunately is not here, also spoke on the option aspect. I agree with Senator Crowley that the very women whom we are trying to advantage here are, by and large, the ones this is targeted at—women who have seen no material benefit from the dependent spouse rebate. There may be a few special cases where the government can make an individual consideration. That is one of the possibilities, but the suggested across the board option would put some women—and probably the very ones this is targeted at who do need money in hand—under enormous pressure from husbands who wanted that dependent spouse rebate to remain.

PARA.TAB: We should not put those women in this position; it simply should be a transfer from one system to the other done as reasonably as possible. As I said before, $4.50 is roughly what we are looking at in terms of loss, but it should never become an option that could lead some women to a situation where their spouse puts enormous pressure on them to sign away their right to $30 a week and to leave him with the dependent spouse rebate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think I will go into the status quo because Minister Crowley is the only one in this chamber who thinks that is what I was talking about. Hansard will show that I was talking about families being disadvantaged. My amendments were designed to make sure that no family was disadvantaged. That is all it was about. Senator Crowley picks up what Senator Lees said: this is a package; we have to have a package and amounts of money going to an increased number of families—and I very much doubt it is the number which Senator Crowley says—but a number of these will gain an advantage. PARA.TAB: Senator Crowley picks that up and says that this is what it is all about and then says that my amendments will affect only a very tiny number of families. If it is to affect a very tiny number of families, we cannot compensate by taking the money off those families to give it to the others at all.

I am not going to repeat myself, but if we are talking about the overall package situation, about the government's attitude towards child care, let us discuss that and let us see what the mother or father in the home is getting for child care as distinct from those in the paid work force. Some on very high incomes can get up to $61.20 a week without any income test. A couple on $120,000 a year can get $61.20 without any income test. That is if they are out in the paid work force, but here the government is miserly and penny-pinching.

To the struggling family which has a child just turning 16 years of age, to whom the government does not pay the dole, the government says that is the responsibility of the parents. They have to pick that up. Now under the DSR they do get a small extra amount, but under this legislation they will not; the government will cut them off. There is no means test for those out in the paid work force, the well-heeled public servants and so on, but the government imposes one here.

Whilst talking about income tests, I ask the minister: what is the definition of `income' here? I have pointed out in my speech in support of my amendment what could be included in amounts now as compared with the DSR. An income means any moneys received, even if it covers gifts. I ask the minister: what about regular housekeeping payments from a husband to a wife? Could they be considered income for social security income test purposes, although obviously not intended. Let me get a response to that.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, in answer to the last part of the question. That is to whether or not the redistribution within a household of income from a husband to a wife is counted as income for the purposes of social security. The answer to that is no.
—Why? Could the minister point to the piece of legislation that says that?
—No, I cannot, at this stage. It may be, as a matter of fact, you are about to help us.

—Yes, I am. By the way, my amendments do not depend on this, but it is a bit of fun. The definition of `income' in the social security legislation includes a periodic payment by way of gift or allowance or a periodic benefit by way of gift or allowance. That is part of the definition in the Social Security Act.

PARA.TAB: The act goes on to exclude domestic payments, but in the Social Security Act `domestic payment' has a meaning given by subsection 3 of section 8 and provides:

SPEECH.PARA: a payment received by a person is a domestic payment for the purposes of this act if (a) the person receives the payment on the disposal of an asset of the person (b) the asset was used immediately before the disposal by the person or the person's partner for private or domestic purposes and (c) the asset was used by the person or person's partner for those purposes for (i) a period of 12 months before the disposal or (ii) if the secretary considers it appropriate a period of less than 12 months before the disposal.

That is what it says about income; it is interesting, is it not? If the literal interpretation holds, any payment that is made by a husband to a wife on a regular basis is income for the purposes of the social security legislation. It is a very interesting question although a diversion from the main area of concern. I certainly would be interested in being shown the part of the social security legislation that says it is not to be regarded as income.

PARA.TAB: Leaving that very interesting diversion to one side, I come back to the burden of my amendments. Let me not argue, as the Minister for Family Services (Senator Crowley) has tended to do in this committee stage, about the principles of the legislation. We could argue forever about the treatment meted out to those parents who prefer or choose to care for their children at home compared with the treatment of those who choose or are required to place their children in institutional child care. There is no way that a spouse with a net gain of $2.60 a week will feel that that is a true recognition of the value of the work that he or she does at home.

I bear in mind the point made by Senator Panizza. No doubt he was asking those questions because a number of people in the paid work force will have $27.40 less in their pay packet from September of this year and will be a bit concerned about it. At some other stage I will be asking how the government intends to ensure that people take up HCCA. If one spouse says that he or she will not give his or her TFN, the government may not be able to compel it. There is a provision in the legislation for waiver, but how long will people have to wait for that to occur?

I would like to know at some stage how many wage and salary earners receive the HCCA payments weekly or fortnightly, as compared with the DSR, because they have put in a concession form. The minister has said that, of persons in receipt of the dependent spouse rebate, 50 percent get it every year and 50 percent get it fortnightly. I do not suggest the minister would know the answer now, but I would like an answer at some stage, if possible.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Harradine is right; I do not know those figures. We do not have accurate figures and we cannot give him anything more than a guesstimate. But I note his comments.

PARA.TAB: Secondly, he is also right about creating diversions, which is not something of a novelty for Senator Harradine. He is good at it, and it was a good diversion. But if he were to go out into the community and say, `We regard regular payment of income from a husband to a wife as assessable for the purpose of this, that and the other thing', his own political astuteness would tell him that that would not be a winnable argument—

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not talking about winnable arguments, but about legal definition.

—Senator Harradine says it is definitional, but I am saying that, politically, it would not be a winnable argument. How would he establish regular transfer and all those other things? It is very clear, in common and colloquial understanding, that if the husband passes some of his pay packet to his wife, it is not regarded as income for the purpose of these definitions. I do not think there is any doubt about that nor that it is in dispute.

PARA.TAB: I want to make a couple of points clear. There was the odd flourish of rhetoric from Senator Chamarette. She is not going to delete that from her repertoire. She was quoting me lines such as `resistance to change'. I do not mind responding with a little flourish now and then myself. If she is minded to support Senator Harradine, she needs to understand that, essentially, she is saying that there is justification for a family with a 24-year-old student being eligible for HCCA while all families lose the basic family payment when the child reaches 18. On the one hand, she is saying that a sole parent pensioner should lose the pension when his or her child turns 16; on the other hand she is saying, `We are here to preserve the rights of a 24-year-old student to the higher level of dependent spouse rebate now cashed out as HCCA'.

Firstly, as far as achieving balance is concerned, that is not a very defensible position. Secondly, it is hard to imagine any 24-year-old student who does not earn $1,785 under the current arrangement; and those who do are currently not eligible for the higher rebate. Thirdly, as I understand it, as long as one child in a family is 16 or under, HCCA will continue. If there are three or four children in a family, provided one child is under 16, the HCCA payment will continue to that family. Therefore, students aged 18, 19 and 20 can still be eligible under this legislation. I am asking Senator Chamarette to rethink her position because, by the time we take those bits and pieces out, the amendment that Senator Harradine has moved will be very small.

I like the way the argument goes here. If the government takes something away from people, to quote Senator Harradine, we are `stripping them of their payments'. If the government is paying something, he calls it a `miserly, mean little bit of money'. Senator Harradine should make up his mind because we are talking about the same amount of money. Whether the government is stripping people of a great advantage or paying them a miserly little bit, depends on how one looks at the argument. It is a good argument and a good piece of theatre from Senator Harradine—I do not mind it at all; he should take a curtain call—but we are talking about the same amount of money. The 55,000 or more families who will enjoy the home child-care allowance, cashed out in their hands each fortnight at a slightly higher rate, will not necessarily regard it as a miserly little bit of payment. On all the evidence that I have, they cannot wait for that payment to start. If it is a major asset that is being stripped from families for students, we should be a little more generous in the way we view what the government is paying. Those families are looking forward to that payment and will find it a big advantage.

Senator Harradine almost raised his voice about the injustice of comparing the cash rebate to the home child-care allowance. Out in the community somehow some people are being persuaded that this home child-care allowance is not a great or very significant payment. It is an extraordinary change. We have all agreed that it is conceptually very important.

TALK.START.PARA: —Two dollars sixty!

—For many women it is $30 because they have never seen the other $26 or $27 and they will be very appreciative that they will now benefit from it. The payment has gone from $2.60 to $2.65 to $2.70 to $2.87. Thus we are talking about an increase of $3 a week extra for the cash dependent spouse rebate. However, Senator Harradine argues that this is a miserly amount of money and persists in comparing that with $60 paid to a family, with no income test, for child care—a millionaire's cash rebate!

PARA.TAB: Let us put some facts on the record. The home child-care allowance is a maximum flat rate of $30 a week, irrespective of the number of children in the family. The child-care cash rebate is $28.20 a week for one child and $61.20 for two or more children. Unlike the home child-care allowance, one does not just get it. One has to spend three times that amount of money on child care with an accredited child-care provider to be eligible for the rebate. It is not a handout—`Here's the money; go spend it on child care'.

If one spends at least $110 for one child or $220 for two children with a registered carer in a licensed child-care arrangement, formal or informal, one is eligible for up to $61.20 a week. So it is not an exact comparison to say, `You're getting a miserly $2, but the person over there is getting $61'. That is not a fair comparison. I have never heard anyone from the other side argue that we spend a very large number of child-care dollars on the occasional care which is specifically provided for parents at home.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, you don't.

—Yes, that is so. Senator Harradine must not shake his head like that because that is a clear indication that he has either not understood or he is determined not to understand it. There are also payments to assist parents with the care of their children in the community, particularly occasional care and the allocation of money for playgroups.

PARA.TAB: More could be said about comparing women at home to women in the work force, but the argument that is being run at the moment is a sad one. It goes back to the days when women at home were set up to be at war with women in the workplace. We know that most women in their adult lives will spend some time at home and some time in the workplace. They are being assisted by this government in the move from one place to another, into or out of work, from the home into the workplace. They are being given assistance by way of child care, by changed arrangements to give them opportunities to study and train and assistance in employment. They are now being assisted with the home child-care allowance—a payment that recognises the contribution of the spouse, usually the mother at home.

On the whole, the arguments for this legislation far outstrip the arguments that it should be amended in the way suggested by Senator Harradine. I take the points raised by the honourable senator, but I do not find them persuasive in the overall scheme of things.

The last question that Senator Harradine asked—and it was a point raised by Senator Panizza—was how we would police whether or not people are taking up the home child-care allowance. We will not have to because it is a voluntary arrangement. Families do not have to apply for home child-care allowance if they do not wish to, but I will be very surprised if they do not. As the dependent spouse rebate at the higher rate will not exist, families will be eligible to continue to get the dependent spouse rebate. But most families who have the option of a lower amount of money paid by the tax system into the husband's account or a larger amount of money paid directly to them per fortnight will not face too hard a choice.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to support what my colleague Senator Patterson had to say. We had a decent debate on the second reading in the Senate last week. A lot of valid points were raised which the minister refused either to listen to or to take heed of.

—I take the committee to clause 927 which includes a means testing provision for HCCA. It states that HCCA will be means tested with a low threshold of $282 per annum. PARA.TAB: The minister has imported the taxation provisions into the social security legislation. She complained that I was doing that with my amendments. She was complaining that I was importing the Taxation Act income test into the social security legislation. Now she is importing the means test from the taxation legislation and placing it into the social security legislation. She cannot have it both ways.

What she has done is put the means test provisions of the taxation law into the social security law. Many of the members of the committee will know where that $5.42 came from—she would not know. The government has imported something from the taxation legislation of 1936 into the social security legislation of 1994, and it has done it without thought.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was waiting for the minister to answer Senator Harradine.
—And yourself.
—And me, of course. I take this opportunity to ask the minister whether she is going to answer the concerns that I raised last time I spoke.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—By arrangement—and I am sorry I have not consulted with the Greens—there is a brief two minute statement I want to read in response to the committee's consideration of the Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Bill and cognate bills. I note that the package of agricultural and veterinary chemicals bills has been considered by the Senate Standing Committee on Rural and Regional Affairs. In particular, I am pleased that a majority of the committee recommends that the seven bills be agreed to without amendment.

PARA.TAB: I note that the committee has raised some issues which should be reviewed in the future. These include: public access to information; cost recovery, including community service obligations; third party appeals; and control of use of chemical products after retail sale. In this regard, I would like to point out that in the development of the national registration scheme, the establishment of the National Registration Authority and the preparation of these bills, there has been an almost unprecedented level of consultation with all stakeholders—including community, environment and public interest organisations.

In particular, the exposure draft bills benefited substantially from being released for public comment. This consultation canvassed the issues raised by the committee and resulted in a substantial number of amendments which have previously been incorporated into the bills. Notwithstanding this comprehensive program of consultation, I am happy to agree to the recommendation that the agricultural and veterinary chemicals legislation will be reviewed after 18 to 20 months of operation to address the issues noted above. Furthermore, I note the dissenting report by Senator Bell raises the same issues; however, Senator Bell argues that they should be addressed now rather than in 18 to 20 months. I agree with the committee's views that the issues should be considered after a suitable period of operation.

A number of submissions presented to the committee expressed concern about control of use matters. I wish to make the point that the Commonwealth has only limited powers in this field—for example, use by trading corporations, use in the territories, and use in the course of interstate trade. In general, these matters constitutionally are state responsibilities. It needs to be recognised by all of us that without the states' agreement to enact further legislation, there are constitutional impediments imposed on the Commonwealth relating to the measures it can take in respect of control of use of chemical products.

However, I emphasise that the Agricultural and Resource Management Council of Australia and New Zealand has requested the agricultural and veterinary chemicals policy committee to examine the issue of control of use. A working party has been established, which includes representatives from the National Farmers Federation and the chemical industry. The terms of reference include defining the scope of control of use activities; developing an equitable mechanism for funding control of use programs; taking into account the recommendations of the Prices Surveillance Inquiry into the price of farm chemicals; and recommending the most appropriate way to harmonise control of use programs across the states and territories.

In the performance of its functions and powers, the NRA is to have regard to the government's policy in relation to the principle of ecologically sustainable development. This includes seven guiding principles, of which one is the precautionary principle. It is important to recognise that the NRA has a duty to fulfil all of its functions, including those which some submissions to the committee serve to amplify over other functions.

In respect of public access to information, the provisions of the bills have been drafted to facilitate maximum access to information within government policy. The commercial exploitation of confidential commercial information will not be entertained by the government. To ensure that the main interest groups are kept informed of relevant agricultural and veterinary chemical matters, a direct mailing list is being developed so that these groups will be advised by a consolidated notice from the NRA and, consequently, they will not need to hunt through daily newspapers looking for notices. This will be more effective and efficient for all concerned. I thank the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the Agricultural and Veterinary Chemical Bill 1993 and the six other bills, which represent a historic national approach to the registration of agricultural and veterinary chemicals. The old scheme operated under the jurisdictions of the eight states and territories. Now, after a quarter of a century of discussion, it is about to be replaced. The states and territories agreed on a common approach only in 1991. The Commonwealth took over the evaluation of agricultural and veterinary chemicals in July 1992, but the actual registration has, until now, remained with the states.

PARA.TAB: In July 1993, legislation supported by the federal coalition established the National Registration Authority, the NRA, which contributed to the development of this legislation. The bills provide the NRA with a full range of functions and powers and represent the final step in the development of a national registration scheme. Importantly, this legislation is supported by the agricultural and veterinary chemicals industry, the National Farmers Federation, Commonwealth agencies involved in the scheme, and state and territory agricultural agencies. The Agricultural and Veterinary Chemical Bill imposes the Agvet code in the Australian Capital Territory. The states and the Northern Territory will legislate to adopt the code and will have 12 months in which to do so.

In order to reduce the complexity of the bill, offences will continue to be offences against the laws of the states or territories, although the Commonwealth Director of Public Prosecutions will be empowered to prosecute for offences. The Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Products (Collection of Levy) Bill provides a user-pays mechanism, meaning the NRA is obliged to recover its full costs from industry. Originally, the government said the requirement would be phased in over four years, but it is now anticipated that the scheme's costs will be fully recovered in 1995-96, with well over 80 per cent in 1994-95.

The NRA will be responsible for assessing whether a levy payment is required in the amount of that levy. Normally, the levy will be based on the sale or disposal of chemical products. Hopefully, this body will keep its administration lean so that costs do not get out of hand. No-one wants another body like AQIS in terms of the relationship between its efficiency and operating costs and the burden those activities place on industry.

The Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Code Bill is the major component of the package. It enables the NRA to evaluate and, if it is satisfied on grounds of human and environmental safety, to approve the active constituents to Agvet chemical products, to register the products enabling their lawful possession and sale, and, importantly, to approve the label which must be affixed to the container. The bill also allows the NRA to license manufacturers of those chemicals. The overriding criteria to be addressed by the NRA include public health, occupational health and safety, the environment, product performance, and trade and commerce.

The NRA can also reconsider an existing registered chemical product to ensure that it continues to meet current safety and performance standards. The authority may suspend or cancel the registration if appropriate. Permits to use unregistered chemicals may be issued for trials or experiments in order to determine whether an application for registration should be made. The legislation also allows the National Registration Authority to consider the results of any trials or experiments carried out in other countries. The aim is to remove unnecessary duplication and expense for companies which have developed and/or registered products overseas.

The advantages of agricultural and veterinary chemicals are well acknowledged. The Bureau of Rural Resources, as it was then known, in evidence to the Senate Select Committee on Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals in Australia, claimed that if farm chemicals were not used, 30 per cent of the world's agricultural product would be lost, in addition to the 20 to 40 per cent which was lost annually because of the effect of weeds, pests and diseases.

The Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Association, now known as Avcare, in evidence to the same committee, estimated that in 1988 the value of increased production by Australian farmers, resulting from the use of pesticides in their activities, amounted to $3.2 billion per year. Avcare also estimated that the withdrawal of chemicals from Australian agriculture would have reduced farm output in 1988 by some $7 billion. The complete withdrawal of sheep blowfly treatments alone would have caused production losses of some $465 million per year.

Avcare believes, and its belief is reinforced by evidence from the United States, that every dollar spent on Agvet chemicals adds $4 to the value of Australian production. It is estimated that in 1992-93, Australian farmers spent $720 million on agricultural chemicals and a further $290 million on veterinary chemicals—a total of just over $1 billion; boosting agricultural production by a massive $4 billion annually. The benefits, in other words, are extremely substantial. Reduced or minimum tillage in agricultural production, cropping production, provides a great example of the benefits to agricultural production.

Ongoing study and research in this area will obviously expand knowledge and improve results as we work towards managing sustainable development in agriculture in this country. Certainly, the wise and sensible use of chemicals has an extremely important role in maintaining agricultural production and, at the same time, helping to maintain the quality and diversity of our soils. Agricultural agriculture is an enormous employer of technology and of modern methods. For example, an Australian company is seeking permission to run field trials of cotton plants which have been genetically engineered to improve their resistance to caterpillars and, paradoxically, the herbicide Round-up.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise tonight to make some brief comments about the coal strike which is currently spreading outside New South Wales to Queensland. Nobody, especially the 25,000 coalminers employed in New South Wales and Queensland, can seriously believe the latest strike will cause a renegotiation of the Japanese coking coal prices. In fact, it will have quite the opposite effect.

PARA.TAB: When Australian coal executives sit down with the Japanese again next year this strike will be used as an example of how unreliable Australia can be and could be, and it can only force prices down further. Tonight I appeal to the average Australian coalminer to look objectively at the results of the current strike. I appeal to them to look beyond the rhetoric spun by their hardline, myopic coal union leaders. There are other ways to pass on a message to their bosses—ways acceptable to both parties.

To put it simply, this strike is the equivalent of cutting their own throats. Coal companies face a $26 million a day bill for as long as the mines remain closed. Further, our trade reputation is being irreparably damaged in the international marketplace, which boasts a number of companies and countries that can supply the Japanese coking coal requirements.

Australia's national debt blows out even further while these strikes continue. The strikes will achieve nothing. To expect coal companies to pay workers attending a rally at Parliament House tomorrow is sheer cheek. Some Queensland coalminers, reportedly, will not return home until Thursday because the buses the union has organised will not get back until that day.

Throughout their wheeling and dealing with Japanese steel mills, Australian negotiators have had to steer a tortuous path between sustaining our market share on one hand and remaining viable on the other. I repeat that the surrounding examples of industrial instability do nothing to make us a reputable and credible supplier in the world marketplace.

Apart from the traditional and fierce competition we face in coal sales to Japan from countries such as Canada and the United States, there are emerging exporters like Venezuela, Chile and Indonesia. Unrealistic union proposals to get a better price for our coal will not be the industry saviour. More efficient work practices, greater capability to achieve improvements in productivity and an overall commitment to improving the industrial relations system is the saviour that we are looking for.

Of course, we are also looking for increased micro-economic reform in the ancillary areas such as ports and railways and overriding all those micro-economic reforms is more flexibility and, unfortunately, a further rationalisation of the pits. Once Australia's coalmines are running at peak efficiency they will be positioned to capitalise on an increased world demand which will come about by increased world economic recovery. When this occurs more people will be employed in the industry, and Australia as a whole will benefit enormously.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise for a few minutes this evening to express my personal thanks to the Australian Navy with which I shared 24 hours over last Friday and Saturday. In particular, I observed a wide range of naval exercises off the eastern coast of Australia on board HMAS Torrens. It was an exhilarating experience for me, and one which I summarise as having led me to see the direct professionalism of our navy as exhibited by both officers and sailors.

PARA.TAB: On Friday morning I left Canberra as a passenger on board a Sea King helicopter that flew directly across New South Wales, over Nowra Airport, past Jervis Bay and the Shoalwater River, across the sea to land on HMAS Torrens, a destroyer escort, which was in a fleet of Australian naval vessels. I was winched down from the Sea King helicopter to the bow of the ship, and so began a fascinating 24 hours of naval experience for me.

I recognise the two pilots on the Sea King helicopter and their two support crew. I happened to have met one of them on another occasion when I went by Sea King helicopter from Adelaide to welcome back Success from the Gulf War.

Torrens is one of several destroyer escorts in our navy. It was commissioned in 1971. It has a displacement of 2,750 tonnes, a length of 113 metres and a beam of 12 1/2 metres. It has geared steam turbine engines developing 22,000 kilowatts. It has a speed capability of more than 30 knots. The ship's company is 250. Whilst it does not have a capacity for guided missiles, it does have a 4 1/2-inch gun. It has anti-submarine torpedo capabilities and is a very powerful ship.

On arrival I was welcomed by the captain of the ship, Commander Warwick Gately, and the executive officer, Lieutenant Commander Stephen Hayes, with whom I spent a considerable time individually and together over the next 24 hours. I admire their professionalism. I was impressed by the enormous wealth of experience and knowledge that was reflected in every element of our discussions on every aspect of the ship and its capability.

I was firstly taken to the bridge, to the operations room and officers' area, including the wardroom. Subsequently, at various intervals between exercises, I was shown every part of the ship. There was a man overboard drill. The officer of the watch was a trainee, and I was fascinated to see the responses—which I judged to be superb—of that trainee officer. The trainee officer happened to be a woman, but I am sure the other officers on board would have done an equally excellent job in performing that task which is set quite regularly on all our naval ships.

There was a replenishment at sea exercise whereby Torrens drew alongside the supply ship Success so fuel could be brought in to top up its tanks. This is quite a demanding exercise with minor adjustments having to be made to the direction and speed of the ship being serviced. It certainly demanded a great deal of vigilance on the part of the watch officers.

There was a double replenishment, the other being by cable to a jackstay at the rear of the Torrens. This was followed almost immediately by an air defence exercise in which Australian air force FA18s and F111s attacked the fleet, including the Torrens, the ship that I was on. There were also New Zealand A4 Skyhawk aircraft that are distinguished by their ability to skim the waves, as it were, at very low height in coming in to attack a naval group.Of course, the main demands of this exercise as far as navy was concerned was for the interpreting of radar signals and the translation of the risks from aircraft, not only for the particular ship, but for those being escorted, such as the logistics ship, the Success, to ensure the best defences were put in place so that the ships were safe.

I was quite excited above decks to see these various aircraft whistling past at very low heights in bombing runs and the like, and also much more excited in the operations room to see 20 very well-trained naval officers working as five or six teams, coordinated by the officer translating the radar information to a gunnery command.

The next exercise later the same afternoon was a submarine defence exercise based upon sonar readings. The Torrens has a Mulloka sonar which is an extraordinarily well developed piece of equipment requiring a very sophisticated computer as well as a very carefully built—Australian built, I would even say South Australian built, by EMI—enhancement read-out, which was directly useful in this sonar exercise of defending the fleet against submarine attack, with a view to eliminating submarines attacking the fleet. I will not go into detail, as I imagine some of the detail I was given remains classified, with regard to the capabilities of the Mulloka sonar equipment, but it was splendid to have that explained to me as a visiting senator and to see it in an operational exercise.

Later in the afternoon I was invited to put on fire protection gear and go into the gun, which is about as big as a small room, all on a swivel. It has two barrels. Inside this gun there is a team of six sailors, two loading a breech on one side and two loading a breech on the other. There is a coordinating sailor looking above the two breeches and a person virtually in a periscope position at the top. Whilst the gun was firing there were another half a dozen sailors on the deck below the gun, feeding shells up so they could be placed into the gun. At rapid fire, it was an enormously strenuous activity requiring split second timing. They had to be right on time to make sure the gun kept up its firing rate.

I stood right next to the sailors loading the breeches. I was also able subsequently to leave that rotating gun, go back up to the bridge and watch the impact of the shells that were fired from this enormous gun. When I say enormous, it is a 4 1/2 inch gun. The larger ships in our fleet have automatic loading of such guns. This one is not automatic. It requires the work of about 10 sailors. It is about a 40-year-old mechanism, but I witnessed it to be a very formidable gun.

The exercise went on and on. There was no stopping for the ship's company. It was virtually a 24-hour exercise while I was on board, and had been preceded by exercises for some days. I think there was still a day or two to go. In the early hours of the morning, for about five hours there was the encounterex surface engagement exercise in which three ships in the fleet were sussing out three other ships and, by turning off their radar or by other subterfuges, they evaded the others, thus exercising one other capability required of our naval vessels.

In the midst of all of this, I was taken on a tour of every part of the ship, including the gearing mechanism, from the turbines to the gears to the propeller, which require a constant watch of four naval personnel. Similarly, in another even hotter area, in the base of the ship, there is a series of eight elements in one side of the boilers for one engine of the ship, with the same on the starboard side of the ship. There was a very exacting requirement to watch water levels and pressure points. I was quite struck by the attentiveness of those sailors in the way they were conducting themselves in a quite difficult environment in terms of heat and noise for some hours of their watch.

In my tour of the ship I went to all external and internal areas, including eating areas for sailors, petty officers and officers—three separate areas. The captain eats alone. I had the evening meal with the captain and was able to discuss a wide range of topics with him and ask his advice. I saw the sleeping areas for all elements of the crew, including one mess containing 30 bunks, three high, in an area that I do not think would be experienced by anyone in Australia in terms of such close confinement. There is no doubt that the sailors on board any of our ships are required to be a team, that they are a team and that they really do live cheek by jowl in our ships.

I saw the ablutions areas for all levels of crew of the ship. In particular, I looked at the facilities for women on board the ship. All of our ships need to be ready to take both men and women together. Certainly, what I saw on the Torrens was well thought out and, I believe, very adequate for men and women serving together on a ship.

I thank the officers, petty officers and sailors who were my hosts in what was for me a marvellous visit to one of our naval vessels. I refer to Commander Warwick Gateley, the captain; Lieutenant Commander Stephen Hayes, the executive officer; Lieutenant David Lantry, the mechanical engineering officer; Lieutenant Commander Stewart Winslade; Lieutenant Commander David Sandwell; and Lieutenant Heath Robertson, the navigating officer. There were four females on board, some of whom I met, including the senior one of those on board, Lieutenant Michele Miller. I was delighted to see her displaying such self-confidence and authority when she was officer of the watch. I also met on board the chaplain, some of the division chiefs and some of the sailors, most of whom I did not get to know by name.

I had asked to sleep in one of the ship's triple bunks. So it happened that I climbed on board at about 1.30 in the morning and into the top bunk with at least a foot between my nose and the pipes of the deck above. I had a very comfortable night's sleep in clean sheets and with a cool air vent ventilating the area.

I especially wish to mention the deputy maritime commander, Commodore Chris Barrie, who was also on board the ship. He arrived differently from me but left with me on the Sea King helicopter. I was most grateful that we had the chance to be together on the ship for a fair proportion of the time that I was on board. He certainly answered my questions about all sorts of aspects of the ship that were unfamiliar to me.

I also met on board Commander John McAree, commander sea training who, together with a sea training group, comprised an inspectorate that had come on board to evaluate Torrens in its capabilities on each of these exercises—that is, there was an independent monitor of professional sailors from the navy who were carrying out their own evaluations. I was happy to meet with them. I thank Captain Robertson and his staff from navy here in Canberra, who liaised with my office and made arrangements for this visit.

I have observed a very professional navy. As a senator, I have had the privilege of observing navy personnel when they appear before us in estimates committees or in a Senate inquiry such as the one currently under way. I am deputy chairman of that inquiry into sexual harassment and the need to ensure that we have solutions to overcome sexual harassment in the three defence services. I have now had the privilege of seeing the navy fully exercising at sea, and of observing 250 personnel coordinating as a team and bringing to bear the professional knowledge and skills that are required of each member of that team.

As I was about to be winched off Torrens to come back to Sydney, flying via the Wollongong coast and eventually into Botany Bay, I was delighted that the captain, Commander Gateley, and the No. 2 officer on board, executive officer Lieutenant Commander Stephen Hayes put on their naval caps and, on the bridge, gave me the honour of presenting to me a plaque of HMAS Torrens, which is now already displayed in my room here in Parliament House. They also gave me the same issue of T-shirt and naval cap that is common to their sailors. I assure the sailors of Torrens that I wore them with a great sense of honour when I went surfing yesterday with my third son. I note that the motto of Torrens is `Faith and fortitude'. I certainly wish every strength of faith and fortitude to the company of Torrens. I thank all of its members for the experience that I was given as a visiting senator.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 19 October 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) Is it the practice of the Australian Taxation Office (ATO) to demand information from taxpayers by telephone with the only identification being a first name.
(2) Was `Peter from the Tax Department' entitled to demand by phone a taxpayer's tax file number, as happened to Mr Toby St George of Chapel Hill, Brisbane.
(3) Is it normal practice to by-pass tax agents, as occurred in this instance.
(4) Can a taxpayer refuse to provide the information because of doubt about the authority of the person making the query.
(5) What action is then taken by the ATO to obtain the information.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Assistant Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The ATO policy on identification of officers over the telephone is that officers should identify themselves at the commencement of the call. Although the use of full names is strongly encouraged, if an officer objects to giving their name, there is no compulsion to do so.

(2) ATO officers are not entitled to `demand' a taxpayer's tax file number (TFN), although requests for details of taxpayers' TFN's are made quite often by the ATO in the normal course of its business.
(3) The ATO's policy is to deal with the contact nominated by the taxpayer. Where a tax agent is nominated the ATO contacts that tax agent in the first instance.
(4) Yes, the taxpayer is entitled to refuse to provide the information if there is doubt about the authority or identity of the person making the enquiry.

(5) Taxpayers are under no obligation to provide details of their TFN to the ATO. Where a taxpayer chooses not to provide TFN details by telephone to the ATO on the grounds that there is doubt about the identity or authority of the ATO officer, alternative arrangements may be made to the satisfaction of the taxpayer (e.g. an official letter on ATO letterhead). Where a taxpayer chooses not to provide TFN details, the ATO may ask for other information that will enable it to verify the identity of the taxpayer.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 20 October 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) What indicators are used by the Child Support Agency to measure its performance; and (b) what were the results achieved for each of these indicators during the 1992-93 financial year.

(2) Do these indicators include time taken to respond to customer telephone enquiries; if not, why not; if so, what was the average length of time taken for response during the 1992-93 financial year, and (b) have callers experienced delays as long as 40 minutes.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Assistant Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1)(a) The Australian Taxation Office Corporate Plan for 1992-93 featured goals, objectives and strategies for the Child Support Agency (CSA) and corporate standards for service delivery.

The objective for the CSA was to `increase the collection of child support liabilities for disbursement to custodial parents for the benefit of their children by 5% (from 68% in 1991-92 to 73% in 1992-93)'. The following strategies were designed to assist in achieving that objective:
improving the timeliness and accuracy of responses to enquiries and correspondence;
increasing the number of payers having direct deduction of payments from wages and salaries;
reducing the eight week delay between registration and first payment;
increasing the level of enforcement; and
increasing the savings to Government and thus, to taxpayers.

The ATO Client Service Objective was to improve client access to services and the timeliness, accuracy and relevance of our service. The ATO Corporate Plan for 1992-93 outlined plans to establish baselines through client surveys, with the objective of improving on the survey results nationally.
(b) A collection rate of 73% was achieved in 1992-93.
During 1992-93, the CSA implemented a number of measures to improve client access to services as well as the timeliness and accuracy of service delivery. Major measures included:
opening new branches to make it easier to contact the CSA in person and by telephone;
commissioning consultants Jenny Rush and Associates to evaluate CSA telephone client service;
establishing hotline numbers for legal practitioners, social workers and Parliamentarians staff who need to check information for their own clients and constituents;
trialing an arrangement where regular clients were given direct telephone access to their case officers;
upgrading telephone switchboard hardware and queuing mechanisms;
piloting a voice messaging system in Perth which allows clients to phone at any time and, providing they quote a personal identifier number, access their account and payment information; and
improving computer response time so that clients are not kept waiting on the telephone while their personal details are brought on screen.

Senator Margetts should be aware that services do not come under the ambit of the Customs Act and consequently are not included in the Prohibited Export Regulations.
Due to the size of the answer to several parts of the question, I have provided Senator Margetts with the attachments referred to below.
(a) For the period 1 July 1991 to 6 December 1993, there were:
(i) 3,022 permits and licences granted;
(ii) 6 permits or licences denied.

(c) No transfers under the DCP have been denied as per the defence export guidelines.

(3) As there are no goods and services involved in Regulations 14 and 14A of the Customs (Prohibited Exports) Regulations, I assume Senator Margetts is referring to Schedules 14 and 14A which list certain goods prohibited to South Africa and Libya. The export of such goods to these countries requires the permission of the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade or his delegate and so the question should be directed at Senator Evans.

(4) (a) In addition to the Ministerial statement referred to by Senator Margetts, the Defence Policy and Industry Report of November 1992 examined the relationship between Defence and industry. Work arising from the report has been on improving the forms of Government facilitation of defence related exports and international materiel cooperation, on Government policies of regional engagement and on the development of Australian capabilities in support of the Australian Defence Force. A key element of this approach has been to seek to develop bilateral relationships with regional neighbours to develop a shared approach to the acquisition of defence materiel.
The Government supports international materiel cooperation including defence related exports in a number of ways, the most significant being:

Coordination by the Defence Export Program (DEP) of the effort of Commonwealth, State and industry organisations to avoid unnecessary duplication and to present a united Australian position when marketing overseas.

Sharing of relevant information between organisations involved in international materiel cooperation. This includes identification of market opportunities and matching these to known Australian capabilities in industry and Defence.
Senior official missions to countries of strategic relevance to Australia to develop and strengthen bilateral relationships and to acquaint them of Australia's capabilities.
Establishing government to government arrangements to facilitate the development of defence cooperation between Australia and countries of strategic relevance.
The provision of technical expertise from the Australian Defence Force to advise potential buyers on advanced defence technology from a user perspective.

Defence sponsored attendance at relevant defence oriented trade shows where the Australian corporate defence capabilities are promoted, together with the promotion of specific products by Australian companies.

Such activities take place within the context of Australia's strategic, foreign and trade policies which have regard to a broad range of factors, including not only humanitarian concerns (on which the Australian Government has an exemplary record) but also recognition of the right of foreign nations to make adequate and effective provision for their national defence.

(b) Export control policy changes implemented to produce `both a simplification and a tightening of the procedures for the consideration of defence exports' as quoted from paragraph 52 of my statement of May 91 entitled `Defence into the Twenty First Century' are described in paragraphs 53 to 55 inclusive.

(c) (i) and (ii) The Standing Interdepartmental Committee on Defence Exports (SIDCDE) decides what constitutes `lethal or destructive goods, or those determined to be of major military significance' and `sensitive destinations'.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Resources, upon notice, on 1 February 1994:

PARA.TAB: Given that the sale of commodities to Japan over the past decade has been characterised by the Japanese continually renegotiating the price paid throughout the life of a long-term contract to the detriment of our mining industry, and given that South Korea has been trying to become a long-term purchaser of liquefied natural gas from the North West Shelf, but that the North West Shelf consortium have fully committed all sales to Japan on a long-term contract, what is the Government doing to try to ensure that our gas sales are not monopolised by the Japanese, leaving it susceptible to the same degree of manipulation as our coal and iron ore industries.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Resources has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: The export capacity of the North West Shelf is largely committed under long term contracts to major Japanese power and gas utilities. There is short term excess capacity which has allowed spot sales, including one to South Korea and several sales to Spain. These spot sales, which are subject to Government price approval, are small compared with the long term volumes committed to Japanese buyers.

South Korea is forecast to require around 15 million tonnes of LNG a year by early next century and Australia, with its long term development opportunities, will be well placed to meet future Korean demand. To this end, the Government has facilitated discussions between Australia's potential suppliers and buyers of LNG including South Korea. One such mechanism is the High Level Group discussions on energy held periodically by officials of the Department of Primary Industries and Energy with their counterparts in a number of Asian countries, including meetings which involve industry representation.

With respect to iron ore and coal contracts, it is important to realise that many long-term contracts provide for actual prices and tonnage to be re-negotiated on an annual basis. In these annual negotiations, exporters naturally expect to have to meet the conditions prevailing in the market at that time. Annual prices and tonnage therefore depend heavily on supply and demand factors, which in turn reflect the extent of competition in the market at that time.

Given the nexus implied in the honourable senator's question, between the sale of different commodities to Japan and prices paid, it is important to draw a distinction between iron ore and coal contracts which are negotiated on an annual basis, and LNG contracts which are on a long term take or pay basis. The latter are currently linked to movements in crude oil prices and are not subject to annual price re-negotiation.

The Government welcomes, where feasible, further exports of LNG to countries other than Japan. However, this would be a commercial decision involving investment and long term commitment to new development and/or expansion of North West Shelf capacity.
